Extract from Inspector Hamilton's report on the Peguis Centre Indian Day School dated March 6, 1941:

The interior walls are badly smoked and very gloomy. Someone should be employed to wash the school ceiling. The exterior of the school and residence should be painted this summer. These buildings have not been painted for years and present a disgraceful appearance. The lumber is deteriorating due to weather conditions and lack of painting.
Ottawa,
March 13, 1941.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his recent inspection of the Peguis Centre Indian Day School Inspector Hamilton states that the interior walls are badly smoked and very gloomy and that the school ceiling requires washing.

He also states that the exterior of the school and residence should be painted.

I am not yet certain what amount of money will be available in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1941-42 but I would like to receive from you an estimate of the cost of carrying out the work which the Inspector states is necessary.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & ...

Mr. F.J. Clarke,
Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Man.

Ottawa,
December 8, 1941.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on a recent inspection of the Peguis Centre Day School Inspector Hamilton writes as follows:

"The school is in good condition. The teacher's residence has about 8" of water in the basement. This water has been pumped out several times but comes in again within 24 hours. This trouble arose after the well was drilled at the school over a year ago. It not only keeps the house damp but apparently is affecting the cement wall as the foundation at one corner is crumbling badly. It looks as though the gravel used in the wall was not free from clay and probably this is why the water has caused it to crumble. It is perhaps too late now to carry out the repair work necessary, but certainly the matter should be attended to next spring."

In reviewing our files the only reference to the above matter is contained in your letter of November 30, 1939, in which you stated that there was a slight leak around the casing but that you had managed to check it. The Department is surprised that you have allowed the condition mentioned by Inspector Hamilton to continue. Please let me know at once if there is any way of correcting the matter to which the Inspector refers.

Yours truly,

Mr. F.J. Clarke,
Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Man.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Fisher River Agency,
Hodgson, Man., Dec 15/41.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter 136-6-5 of Dec 8/41 re the well at the Peguis Centre School.

This well was not running last winter nor during the past summer until late in the season. It would appear that the casing is loose as the water to the basement comes from outside the casing. I am of the opinion that before any work is done on the well we should call in someone experienced in this particular work.

Your obedient servant,

W. J. Clarke,
Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont
Ottawa,
December 20, 1941.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 15th instant it is considered that you should be able to secure someone who will give you expert advice on what should be done in connection with the well at the Peguis Centre School. It is understood, of course, that you will keep the cost as low as possible.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Extract from Inspector Hamilton's report on the schools of the Fisher River Agency inspected between January 17 and 21, 1944.

Centre Peguis Indian Day School

The interior needs decorating and if possible this should be painted this coming summer.

Last summer both the school and residence were painted outside. Repairs were made to the school foundation and the joists renewed. The school residence was moved and placed on a complete new foundation. All this work has apparently been well done and the buildings are now in good repair.
Ottawa,
February 10, 1944.

EX

Mr. F.J. Clarke, Indian Agent, Hodgson, Man.

In reporting on his recent inspection of the Peguis Centre Day School Inspector Hamilton recommends that the interior of the school be redecorated during the coming summer. As far as I know at present we will have funds available for the purpose. You should let me know early in May what materials will be required, in order that purchase of these can be made before the summer holidays during which time the necessary work can be done.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. F. J. Clarke, Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Man.

With reference to requisition received from the teacher of the Peguis Centre Indian Day School, there is a request for 6 desks. These are made in three sizes: large, medium and small. Please let me know which size is needed.

It is also stated that the interior of the teacher's residence needs redecorating and that a galvanized tank is required for the residence. Please give me more specific information regarding the type and size of tank required. If this can be purchased locally, you should let me know its approximate cost. You should also state what expenditure would be required to redecorate the interior of the teacher's residence.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
528 Dominion Public School,
Winnipeg, Manitoba,
September 15th, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Centre School - Peguis Reserve,
Fisher River Agency.

I called at the Centre School on the Peguis Reserve on September 11th. I found 52 pupils present. 47 were Treaty and 5 non-treaty; of these two belonged to the Farmin G Instructor, Mr. Paterson, and three to the Missionary, Mr. Smith. There are seats for about 28. Of the 52 pupils about 25 are in Grade 1.

To relieve the situation I would suggest authority be granted to purchase a table 6'x3' with benches for the sides and ends. This table is for the pupils in Grade 1, and it could be placed at the front of the room near the teacher's desk. The Dowse Lumber Company, St. Boniface, have quoted the price of $69.00 f.o.b. Winnipeg. No other companies wished to do the work. I enclose the only quotation I could get.

The North and South Schools were not in operation as the teachers had not arrived. No doubt the same condition will exist. If tables are needed may they be supplied?

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
for Manitoba.
AIR MAIL

I enclose herewith reports of my annual inspection of Peguis and Fisher River Schools.

Since payments of family Allowances have come into effect the three schools on Peguis Reserve are badly overcrowded, the one having an enrolment of 72 where 40 could conveniently be accommodated. These three schools have no transom windows nor other ventilation system.

Would it be possible to have transom windows installed as soon as possible?

Yours truly,

C.J. Muller.
Ottawa, 27th December, 1945.

Mr. P.G. Lazenby, Indian Agent, Hodgson, Manitoba.

What the Inspector said regarding South Peguis School applies also to Centre Peguis School although the enrolment is not as large at the latter school.

To improve the ventilation, Inspector Muller suggests a transom window should be installed during the Christmas holidays. Authority is granted for you to have this work done.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Canada.

We refer to your letter of 27th December 1945 in regard to Centre Peguis School and note Mr Muller requests a transom window. We doubt if we could have this done till summer holidays, but will try and have this done over a week end.

Like South Peguis, we could secure the W A Centre Hall for a second room. There is a good stove in this hall, but we would require complete school equipment otherwise, also fuel which could be purchased from the Indians. The rental would be $15.00 per month for the Hall. It's very near Centre School, maybe a quarter of a mile away.

PGL/OT

P G Lazenby, Indian Agent

Note: The teacher for this room would have to live with Miss Clarke, at the Nurses residence, or have a room in the hospital or elsewhere if no accommodation there.

Re: File No. 136-6-5
136-4-5 (E.) - August 13, 1948

Replying to your letter of above date regarding Peguis Centre Indian Day School and Peguis North Indian Day School.

I visited these schools around the middle of June and I found them very much overcrowded. I would certainly recommend that two classrooms be built to take care of these pupils. I do not think we should build expensive buildings. If classrooms could be built without basements and the floors insulated and heated by stoves, one residence would do the two teachers. These classrooms could be built alongside the existing schools.

If you will refer to my report on these schools, dated June 18th, it will give you a fair idea of the existing setup. These buildings could be purchased from the North American Lumber Company and put up for use this winter.

Yours truly,

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,
Surveys & Engineering Branch.

I am sending forward herewith copy of a letter received by this Branch from Indian Agent Clarke, Hodgson, Manitoba. The subject matter of this letter, you will note, is self-explanatory.

It would be appreciated if you could have an engineer undertake an inspection of the teacher's residence at the Peguis Centre Indian Day School on the Peguis Reserve. We are anxious that the repairs to this residence should be undertaken and completed prior to the opening of the school year on October first.

Encl.

Director.
December 2nd, 1942.

Dr. McGill

Re: Teacher's Residence, Peguis Centre Indian Day School, Fisher River Agency, Manitoba.

This will acknowledge receipt of your memorandum of August 17th relative to the above. In the meantime we have been getting reports on this residence, the nature of its site and conditions prevailing there, but before making any recommendation to you we would ask to be advised whether you consider it important that there should be a basement or cellar under this residence.

Briefly the site is not a good one for a residence. It is situated on a narrow strip of flat land between Fisher river and a swamp. The soil is water-logged with water from a swamp, from an open ditch near the residence, and from a flowing well near the residence which was sunk without the necessary casings having been placed in the well when it was drilled.

Probably the best course to follow would be to put a new foundation without any basement under the house either on its present site or on a site a short distance away. If a basement is essential a drain from it to the river would have to be installed with a valve to prevent water backing up into the basement from the river during periods of high water. During such periods water from the surrounding soil would probably seep into the basement and would have to be pumped or bailed out. Another alternative might be to construct the basement with its floor very little below the natural surface of the ground which would necessitate a very large amount of filling being piled about the outside of the house, which would mean considerable expense and would result in a long set of steps from the house down to the road in front being necessary.

Would you kindly advise if you consider a basement under this residence important or essential. If such a basement was intended only for the storage of roots or vegetables for winter use,

(over)
this could probably be taken care of by the construction of a separate root house near the residence.

J. M. Wardle,

Director.
Ottawa,

Re: Teacher's residence, Peguis Centre

Agency, Man.

This will acknowledge receipt of your memorandum of December 22nd, advising that the Indian Agent considers a foundation under this building necessary but that a basement is not required.

As you know this matter has been under consideration by our Engineering and Construction Service and to meet the needs of the situation, bearing in mind the fact that no basement is required, they have advised as follows:

"Under the circumstances, it is felt that as recommended by Mr. Storsater in his report dated September 18th, the building should be moved west approximately 20'. This distance is approximately as far as the property line permits, and would be clear of the existing basement excavation, which should be filled.

"The existing superstructure should be placed on a new concrete foundation 3'6" high and 9" thick, having a footing 1'6" wide and 9" thick. The footing should be placed not lower than the 99 foot elevation shown on Mr. Storsater's profile. This would be approximately 2' below the average existing grade in the vicinity of the residence. After moving the superstructure, the area surrounding the new foundation should be graded for a width of 10' on all sides to elevation 103. By this method the foundation walls would have 4' of..."
"of protection against frost penetration, and the footings would be higher than the reported high water level of the Fisher River, while the main floor of the house would be maintained at the existing 104 foot elevation."

The cost of the work involved would likely be in the neighbourhood of $800, but it is possible that repairs to the house which might become necessary as a result of moving it, might amount to an additional $100.

Will you kindly advise if you wish us to undertake this work in the Spring so that our Engineers can make the necessary arrangements.

J. M. Wardle,

Director.
Ottawa,

Memorandum:

Re: Foundation, Peguis Centre Indian Day School,
Fisher River Agency, Manitoba

Following receipt of Dr. McGill's memorandum of June 30th last, bearing your notation of the 2nd instant, we communicated with Mr. Gow asking him to have his officer superintending work on the teacher's residence examine the school foundation and report to us on the extent and probable cost of necessary repairs.

We have now received Mr. Gow's report dated the 19th instant, in which we are advised that the school foundation is in the same deteriorated condition as that of the teacher's residence, and that the only method of repair is to demolish and replace the existing foundation.

Mr. Gow proposes to lay a footing at the level established by this office for the new foundation to the teacher's residence and pour a new 9" concrete foundation wall to support the first floor joints. By raising the finished grade around the building 1'0", satisfactory frost protection will be afforded.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that when I met Chief Prince and Councillor Prince of the Peguis Reserve at Selkirk on the 16th instant, they informed me that there was now 33 children of school age on that reserve ready to attend school as soon as a school-house and teacher was provided. I told them I would write the Department advising them of the fact and endeavour to ascertain their intentions.

I am inclined to think their haste to have a school-house is with a view of getting Councillor Prince, who is an educated man, the position of teacher.

When Inspector Semmens returned from Ottawa, he told me there was a possibility of another Indian Agent being appointed for the reserves in the middle of Lake Winnipeg with headquarters at the Peguis Reserve. If the Department have this still in view I think it would be well to wait until the Agent was appointed before taking any steps in the matter, because it is hard to decide the best place for building a school-house just from a visit to the reserve, and in all probability there will eventually be enough children on the reserve for two or more schools, in which event great care should be taken to see they are properly located.

Sir,

I beg to enclose a copy of a resolution duly passed at a meeting of the Chief and Counsellors held in the Halfway House on Monday April 25th/13, and a copy of charges and evidence against the teacher of the North Peguis School, Mr. Angus Prince.

I could get no evidence that a third party had witnessed the acts charged against the teacher, and the contradiction in the testimony of Harriet Ellen Stevenson would lend some色彩 to the statement of Mr. Prince that the case was gotten up to injure him.

It is very difficult to obtain reliable evidence; when the person accused is absent the accusation is emphatic, when present the person making the charge has nothing against him but states some one else complained.

However, the girls are not attending the school, whether from a hope of the parents to force the discharge of the teacher, or that the teacher is guilty of the charges I am unable to determine, but it is evident the teacher is not wanted by many parents in his district; I have advised him to resign but he says he is not guilty of the charges and does not understand why he should, and adds he would be willing to resign at the end of the September quarter.

I greatly regret to state that a number of the members of the Peguis Band have embraced the Apostolic Faith, commonly known as Shakers, in the observance of which they sadly neglect duties relying upon Providence to supply their needs, Mr. Prince is also of this faith which no doubt has helped to make him unpopular.

I am of the opinion that the resignation of Mr. Prince would be for the best interests of all concerned.

I have the honour to be

your obedient servant

Dear Archbishop Matheson:

With reference to that portion of Your Grace's letter of the 24th ultimo which is relative to Mr. Harbord, of the Peguis North Indian Day School, I have to report that, for some months, Mrs. Harbord has been undertaking the duties. The Public School Inspector reports Mr. Harbord has no professional qualifications but that Mrs. Harbord has, and he believes her to be the best teacher in the Indian agency. In view of this condition, the Department was satisfied to have the Harbords remain at the school and no steps are being taken to effect a change.

Dear Sir:

Peguis North Indian Day School
Fisher River Agency

I wish to submit the following report on the above school which was inspected February 25, 1941:

Miss A. Eaton is in charge of this school. She met with an accident before Christmas and was off duty for a few weeks, but is now apparently quite well again. Miss Eaton has had years of experience in teaching and is doing good work, not only in the classroom but also among the Indians.

There are 23 pupils enrolled, but I found only 9 present. The average attendance for December was 20.36. The poor attendance is due to the "flu" and bad colds. Two small children died during the week of my visit and many more were sick.

The children are making fair progress. They were clean, but some were poorly clad. All the pupils are instructed in spinning yarn and knitting, and the work seen was indeed quite good. The pupils are also knitting socks and scarves for the Red Cross.

Some plaster is off one side of the room, and when possible, this should be repaired. It is difficult in these outlying districts to secure a competent man to do this work. The stove is also warped beyond repair and is unsafe. A new stove should be provided. A flag is also needed.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Manitoba.

Mrs. Shergold is the teacher in charge. She has a very pleasing personality and is well liked by the pupils.

The roll calls for fifty pupils and the grades are as follows:

| Grade | Pupils |
|-------|--------|
| 1     | 26     |
| 2     | 12     |
| 3     | 6      |
| 4     | 6      |

The attendance has been poor due to the fact that some children live three and four miles away and in addition during November and December many were sick with the "Flu". The pupils attending regularly are making good progress.

This school also needs interior painting. The walls are dark and the ceiling badly discoloured. The exteriors of the school and residence were painted a year ago and are in good condition.

A special effort should be made both by the teacher and Agent to secure better attendance. Perhaps some children enrolled live too far away; but if there is no unusual sickness, the attendance should range around thirty. To date this has not been the case.

Indian Improved Day School - Fisher River

In this school we have Miss Smith-Windsor in charge of the senior room, with thirty-three enrolled, and Miss Macsell in the junior room with forty-three pupils. The attendance has been fair, but there is room for improvement. A number of the Indians have been camped with their families near the lake where they are fishing, and consequently the children could not get to school; however, most of these people have moved back now so that the attendance should be much better.

The pupils are well along in their respective grades and the work seen was well done and neatly set down. I am certain the children are making good progress.

The pupils were all well dressed; many with dresses, skirts, coats and windbreakers made from Army clothing. These were all re-modelled, and the average person would never know the material was from old Army clothes. The sewing Club under the direction of Miss Smith-Windsor has done some excellent work.

The school building is badly in need of exterior painting and if at all possible this should be done during the coming summer. The front and back steps are also badly rotted and must be renewed.

The furnaces appear in good condition and the building was warm and comfortable.

REPORT ON FISHER RIVER AGENCY

Peguis Reserve:

The Family Allowance is certainly a blessing. The teachers state those bringing lunches have fruit, cheese, eggs and good bread. They are much better clothed and indeed the parents state they have sent orders for clothing which could not be supplied. Right now many children have no high rubbers or rubber boots and so are kept home. For days the roads have been almost impassable to walk on except with high rubber boots. I saw a twelve-year old girl come home last week wet to the knees. If we insist on the children going to school under all conditions, we will have plenty of sickness and no doubt many cases of pneumonia.

The Indians have tried to purchase high rubbers locally and from Eaton's and Simpsons. Only the odd pair has been secured. Many children travel from two to four miles, which is a long way even under good conditions. I am convinced the Indians are trying to co-operate and I hope distance, roads, weather and health will be considered on judging results.

More schools are required. On Peguis we need at least three. The building of more accommodation should receive early consideration.

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept' of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to advise the Department that from present indications, there will be at least five new day school teachers required for the school of this agency after the summer holidays, and probably six, as follows:

Peguis North School - 1
Peguis Centre " 2
Peguis South " 2

The above, provided we are able to equip the three Anglican Church Halls for use as day schools, and get teachers for them as well as for the schools already established, and which are much overcrowded.

Miss Una McDonald, who is the present teacher at the Peguis North School, says she will come back again next term, provided another teacher can be secured and the school divided.

There is no teacher at all now at the Peguis Centre School, and this school too should be divided and two teachers provided, one to teach in the church hall.

The present teacher at the Peguis South school, Mrs Hamrlik, has already sent in her resignation, as she wishes to stay with her family on their farm. This school also, should be divided, and two teachers provided.

I have been told, though I have not verified, that Miss Wakentin, one of the teachers at the Fisher River United Church School is not returning after the holidays. If this turns out to be the case, another teacher will be required for this school. I will definitely advise the Department as to this later, after I have seen Miss Wakentin.

As I have already advised the Department, we can rent the three Anglican Church Halls on the Peguis reserve to use for day schools. However, if we are unable to secure the necessary number of teachers, it would be no use equipping these halls with school furnishings. I would therefore respectfully recommend that an early effort be made by the Department to secure the teachers required, and then the equipping of the halls could be proceeded with, and completed before the new school term begins in September next.

Mr. Pomeroy, the teacher at the above noted school, called at the office a few days ago, regarding giving the pupils a holiday the first week in July.

Your returns for the months of March and April 1949 have been received and contents noted. It appears that you are uncertain as to the meaning of some sections of the return:

1. Section 4, the average daily attendance is found by dividing the total actual attendance for the whole school by the number of days the school was in session. 2. Section 6 refers to the number of pupils attending school some time during the month. Section 17 also refers only to those pupils who attended school during the month, and their numbers are shown in a breakdown according to grades. Therefore, sections 6 and 17 must agree. If any children are absent during the whole month they will not be included in either section 6 or 17.

Murdoch Indian Day School

We have checked over the list of school attached to your letter of October 15 and are clear on everything but one point. Before taking definite action with the Treasury, would you please confirm the statement made in paragraph one of your letter. Miss Aime (Mrs. Breule) was placed on our pay list as the junior teacher of the Peguis No. 4 School effective November 15, 1948. We had no knowledge whatsoever that she resigned in February and we are wondering whether there has been some mistake. We have already advised you concerning the return of the two cheques sent to this teacher in over-payment for the month of September.

If the information in your letter of October 15 is correct, then this teacher has been overpaid ever since February as she has not been teaching since than time.

However, our records indicate that Miss Jone was never at the Peguis No. 4 School but that she was appointed on April 25 at the Murdoch School (see Mr. Bowell's letter of April 26, your file 73 (136)). As we sent her a salary letter at the Murdoch School, it is presumed that she must have reported there and taught there until the end of June.

She is, of course, now at the Lake St. Martin Indian Day School.
We will expect to hear from you verifying the statement made in paragraph one of your letter.

There is one other small point raised in your letter with regard to Miss Phoenix. Our records show that she was transferred to the Peguis No. 2 School and that she left the No. 4 School at the end of June. I presume this transfer must never have taken place.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6243, file 533-3, part 1)
Ottawa, December 6, 1927.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that His Grace the Archbishop of Rupert's Land has nominated the services of Mrs. C. Morris as teacher of the Peguis North Indian Day School until midsummer next. His Grace states that Mrs. Morris is the wife of Rev. C. Morris, who has been corresponding with him about becoming the missionary at Peguis. We have informed His Grace that the temporary appointment of Mrs. Morris for the balance of the present school year ending June 30th, next, is approved. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $75 per teaching month. I shall be pleased if you will give Mrs. Morris every assistance you can upon her taking up duties at this school and inform the Department later as to the date when she begins work.

The Rev. Mr. and Mrs. Morris are to be allowed to occupy the teacher's residence until the middle of next summer. You should arrange to have the furniture purchased and any minor repairs made at the residence as authorized in our telegram of the last instant. You should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

T. R. L. MacInnes,
For Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

H. G. B. Templeman, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Man.

Ottawa, November 19, 1910.

Rev. Sir,

The establishment of a day school on the new Peguis Reserve has been receiving consideration by the Department and as you have recently visited this locality it is desired to have a full report from you upon the existing conditions. You should state how many Indians are now located on the reserve and whether they are so situated that a school can be erected at a central site. If so you should deal fully with the matter of location as well as the size and style of building that would be required to accommodate the children.

The Indians are pressing for the establishment of a day school and the Department is prepared to meet their wishes if the time is now opportune.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary

Rev. J. Samsara,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.
As an objection to this class of school it might be urged that it will take much time to get it started. All the next summer would pass before it could be prepared for active work and in the meantime the children would be without any advantage.

Again it would cost very much more than the day schools even if two of them were built.

A third objection might arise out of the fact that any school of this type should have a large constituency to draw from.

Still another difficulty arises from the fact that the situation is remote and at present rather inaccessible by boat or rail routes and Officers might object to the location and freighting would be expensive.

All this is granted and these things are worthy of consideration, however Old Fisher River Reserve has a population has a population of nearly 500 and the New Reserve has about 25 making 725 people with 325 children and if the proposed school has accommodation for say 50 children it will be seen that there need be no lack of pupils.

Then the railroad is now within forty miles of the New Reserve and is coming nearer every year and boats land at the present time within twenty miles of Peguis and they enter the Old Reserve at the present time, without difficulty. This makes the question of transportation more simple than it appears at first sight.

Personally I would be disposed to recommend that the School be erected on Government land between the Reserves and that it be made to serve them both and that it be a non denominational institution from the start and all the way through. This would I think do away with all feelings of jealousy between the Reserves and would allow of the closing of the present day School at Old Fisher River and would in the long run be the most effective way of educating the Indian children of the locality.
The religion of the old Reserve is Methodist and Shaker. The new Reserve is wholly Episcopalian and there must be an air of independence maintained so as to suit the parties interested.

The people at Peguis are really the pick of the St Peters people and are worthy of consideration.

Now I have reviewed the situation as I see it and have made recommendations from my point of view and am prepared to receive any direction the Department may wish to give and see that orders are carried out whether they are in accord with my views or not.

If Day Schools are ordered the building should be 30 ft long by 32 feet wide and 10 ft high with an arched ceiling so as to admit of ample breathing space.

If only one School is built it should be built at the east end where the greatest number of people are found. I would also say that the site chosen should be nearly two miles from the eastern boundary.

I have the honor to be

Your Obedient Servant

Inspector of Indian Agencies

The Secretary

Department Of Indian Affairs

Ottawa

Inspector Semmens' Report on the Fisher River School Question.

Inspectors Office
376142 Winnipeg Manitoba
November 22nd 1910

Reply to your favor No 347989 of Nov 19th 1910

Sir,

Having recently visited the Fisher River Country especially the Peguis Reserve and having met the Indians in Council and reviewed with them the great need of school privileges; I am constrained to make a few observations in regard to the educational question, all the more so because the Department is anxious to act promptly in the way most suited to the needs of the people.

The number of houses now built at Fisher River on the new Reserve is 41. The population is 225 and the number of children is about 100. These children at the present time are running wild and the parents are clamoring for the benefits of a School and a properly qualified teacher. The need of action is very apparent.

The important question however is how to act so as to meet the requirements of the case and secure the greatest good for the greatest number.

As Day Schools are all that these people have had so far, it is perhaps wise to think first of them. They are most easily supplied and are the cheapest form of accommodation furnished by the Department and may be thought most advisable by some because they can be set in motion in the shortest possible space.

It is clear that one School will not do for this Reserve. The people are settled at opposite ends of
the Reserve. When the first comers arrived they entered from the Old Fisher Reserve side. There was ahead of them some 6 miles of old Reserve 4 miles of space between Reserves and naturally enough they were glad to camp and select locations on the easterly side of the Peguis Reserve. After one or two had settled there others followed until a large cluster of houses was found not far inside the lines of their new heritage. Others coming later were compelled to go farther in.

Then there came a time when it was found that a nearer road could be found and men came in from Ardal and Vedder to the westerly limit of the Peguis Reserve and finding excellent land there choose locations far west and their friends and relations followed them and a large cluster of houses sprang up on or near the western boundary.

The Government building now called "Halfway" was built on a fractional lot near the centre of the Reserve and there is a considerable space on either side of this building not yet settled upon.

Here then you have two distinct sections one east one west. One School will not do. If we have Day School work done, it is plain that there must be two Schools built not one, for one School could not be so placed as to meet the needs of the opposite sections.

Or putting it differently, the Reserve is say 12 miles across. Most of the people live in the first three miles of either side and the spaces between represent about 6 miles. Children could not walk to a central School without being compelled to go from three to six miles to School and the same number of miles to return. Indian children are not ambitious enough to do this and the parents are too lenient towards their offspring to ask them to do it and I fear it would not be wise for us to ask it.
The kind of School House to be built would of course be log walls dovetailed at the corners on a foundation of stone. Logs are cheap the Indians will haul them and be glad of the labor involved which brings them food and clothing. Indians will erect the building and if need be the lumber now in our yard may be used to cover and complete them. Not a days skilled labor from outside will be necessary. It can all be done by the people of the Reserve. It can all be done quickly. If built wholly frame more quickly still.

The cost of building will not be great. I should say that the following estimate is sufficiently generous:

| Item                          | Cost   |
|-------------------------------|--------|
| 60 logs at 40 cents per log   | $24.00 |
| 50 days work at 1.50 per day  | 75.00  |
| 4 cords of stone at 4 dollars  | 16.00  |
| 10 Bushels of lime at 1.00 per B.| 10.00  |
| Rations for 50 days at 50 cts per D.| 25.00  |
| Unforeseen expense            | 25.00  |
| **Total**                     | **175.00** |

Note

All lumber and other material to be supplied from our own Yard at Peguis.

As a matter of fact however the people do not want day Schools. They ask the Department for a Government managed Boarding School. They are averse to Church management of any School. They ask for Government supervision and that only. They wish for a Boarding School and that only.

I am inclined to second their request for in my experience it is The School that accomplishes the most good and is the most satisfactory to all concerned.

This might be placed in the centre of the Reserve and be entirely satisfactory. There is good drainage and good pure water and good soil and good hay privilege and plenty of children to fill it in the first month.
Ottawa, December 23, 1910.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 22nd ultimo reporting on the matter of establishing schools on the Peguis reserve.

In reply I beg to say that it is not the intention of the Department to erect a boarding school at this point and it is thought advisable to carry out your suggestion to put up in the meantime two log buildings. The sites for these should be carefully chosen, should be high and dry, easily drained and have suitable lands surrounding them for gardening operations. As to the construction the Department would like you to go more carefully into the matter and obtain a detailed estimate of the cost of all material that will be used. In the meantime the necessary logs may be got out so that active building operations can be commenced as soon as conditions will permit in the spring. When making your estimate you should include the necessary doors, windows, etc., and the Department thinks also that it would be well to sheet the interior.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Rev. J. Simmons,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

WINNIPEG, MAN. April 28th 1911

Sir,

April 24th I wired Department as follows:

"Kindly wire me hundred dollars Montreal Bank tomorrow. Must Visit Peguis Wednesday"

On the 26th inst the telegram was replied to by a wire to Montreal Bank placing to my credit one hundred Dollars accountable Cash.

My reason for going out was to arrange for the immediate erection of the Schools and to pay for freighting done.

As intimated in former correspondence there was an absolute refusal to work for the customary wage of $1.50 and rations. This arose from the fact that most of the Peguis men are engaged at Arborg cutting cordwood at .65 cents per cord and as they cut four cords a day they earn $3.40 per day and board themselves. It was impossible therefore to induce them to work for $1.50 per day and board, an amount which hitherto has been regarded as fair wages when men are rationed.

Just as I was leaving for Peguis Mr Sinclair came in to the Office followed by Mr Harper the Farm Instructor and Chief William Prince. Under these circumstances it was not necessary for me to go out as all matters were satisfactorily arranged here. Work will proceed forthwith, on the terms allowed by the Department with one meal given at noon.

I have the honor to be

Your Obedient Servant

LAKE WINNIPEG INSPECTORATE

WINNIPEG, MAN. August 31st 1911

Sir,

I beg to report that in accordance with my promise in my letter of XXXXX August 15th No 4 I proceeded to Leguis Reserve Fisher River via Arborg Station on the 19th inst returning on the 22nd. This journey was undertaken so that I might make satisfactory answer to your letter No 347980 of August 10th 1911.

I found that both the Schools ordered to be built are in course of erection and well under way.

The North School about completed. Roof on, floor down, doors and windows in place, everything done but chinking with moss and plastering. The Church of England are holding service in this building and it is substantial and roomy. Size 20 by 30 and 12 feet high.

I think that the Windows must be refitted and that stone must be placed underneath and the building be allowed to settle before the plaster is put on between the logs and for this purpose we are allowing about two weeks more to elapse but it will be ready for use October 1st 1911.

The South School is not so far advanced but the Chief and the Farming Instructor have promised to have it ready by the same date October 1st.

At present the walls are up, roof on, shingles complete, windows in floor ready to lay boards. No stone under yet and no chinking with moss done.

The logs are fine and the walls are well built and the building is substantial and will last for many years.

I recommend that a strong rod with tightening Screw be placed in each of these Schools across the centre ow-

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6244, file 533-5, part 1)
owing to the length of the building (30 feet). There might be some sag outward from the centre if this were not done and it would be well to prevent the possibility of this. These rods should be of inch iron with heads and braces outside and strong double Screw Joiners in the middle of the interior to draw the sides well in.

I enquired about a boarding place for the Teachers and found that it would not be desirable to send lady teachers for the present. Gentlemen could only find poor accommodation and might have to walk miles each day to get that.

This difficulty suggested the idea to my mind that perhaps Indian Teachers might do for the first winter. Some of the Indians are in favor of this but the majority are opposed to it. It was thought that Indian teachers become high-headed when placed in a superior position, that the children would take advantage of them and would not be subordinate, and that there would not be proper guarantee of proper moral supervision.

This then presents the whole question before the Department and I may add to what has been said that there can not be found one certificated teacher among the Indian people, resident at Fisher River, though some might be able to conduct the very elementary work necessary.

It will of course be necessary to order desks and other school supplies for both these schools at an early date. It is desirable that these supplies be sent in by way of Arborg Station C.F.R. because nearer and cheaper than any other way. They can be bought in Winnipeg from the Moyer Company if thought desirable and sent direct from here.

Ceiling and Collar Beams must be added before the cold weather but at present there is no lumber available for these purposes and it must be purchased and shipped out and an order to do this must be sent by the Department to the Agent or Inspector without much delay.

Nails will also be necessary and stoves and piping.
Storm Windows will be required and there are none available at Peguis. Some one should be authorized to purchase all these necessary things and see them through and see them placed in position.

In my judgement a carpenter should be employed to put on the finishing touches and make the schools presentable and it would take a months work to complete everything. Indians can not be relied upon to work when and how we may please. Especially will this be true as the fall fishing comes on. Mr Harper is not a mechanic and Mr Sinclair is certainly not.

Be it understood by the Department that the only way of moving freight from Arborg to Peguis is by team and the roads are abominable and teams are valued at $6.00 per day and found which equals $6.25 six dollars and twenty five cents.

I wish that general instructions should be issued and a certain sum of money be placed at disposal of proper Officer to carry out these instructions and present statements and receipts after as it has been difficult to run ones face for work required the Department will consider this and direct accordingly.

I have the honor to be

Your obedient Servant

John [Signature]

I very gladly accept the responsibility of seeing to the completion of the school buildings at Peguis Reserve.

I have engaged a competent Carpenter and am sending him in by way of Arborg by the next Train which leaves here on Friday the 8th inst.

He will procure and have sent to Arborg the necessary lumber and will finish the work and I will go out and pay the bill for wages on the 16th inst or on the 25th which is more likely to be the time when work will be completed.

I will endeavor to appoint men to start the work of teaching on October 1st as before intimated following out your direction in the letter quoted above.

I will have the iron rods prepared and taken out with the Carpenter and will see that the work is done in proper fashion.

I found in your letter £150.00 in Cheque No 939 which I hold as accountable cash for the purpose of paying wages done on Schools.

It was impossible to employ Indians during the harvest time and after that came the fall fishery when most of them go down to the lake to lay up supplies of fish. As soon as they returned from the fisheries we got them to work and both schools are now under way.

I am submitting herewith an account showing work done under the superintendence of Farm Instructor Peter Harper. This account will speak for itself as to the cost of doing the work which I must admit was greater than I anticipated. This increase of expense resulted from the fact that in order to secure the services of the Indians we were compelled as per your permission by telegraph to pay $2.00 a day for the work done by all Indians.

As directed by you I sent in lumber for cellar beams and ceiling and with that sent a carpenter to complete the work and leave everything shipshape so that the schools might be properly warmed in the cold winter weather. Stoves have been sent up, good heavy stoves with plenty of piping so that I think there is no doubt about their being able to keep warm. I am writing to the Indian Chief asking him to see that his people may supply wood immediately and plentifully for use in the cold weather.

Should the Department think this a high rate of wages I must explain that I tried in many directions to employ a man at a lower rate but when wages in the city of Winnipeg were being paid at 50 cents an hour for nine hour days it was not possible to induce any one to go to Peguis and work and board himself for less. Sir,

I beg to report that I have made a trip of Inspection to the Peguis Reserve on the Fisher River, Manitoba.

Schools.

I sent forward yesterday reports showing Inspection of the two Schools recently completed and I need not refer to that matter here. I only wish to deal in this letter with the work of erecting the buildings.

When I went out in August last I asked Mr. Farm Instructor Harper how long it would take to complete the buildings. He said he could have them ready by the first of September. I gave him until the first of October and reported to the Department that the Schools would certainly be ready by that time. Difficulty arose over Harvesting and Fishing and I saw that the Schools would be delayed unless we had someone to depend upon other than Indians. Hence my recommendation that a carpenter be sent in to finish. Dupont was sent and the work was hastened.

On arrival of the Carpenter it was found that much of the work done on the North School was imperfect and would have to be done over again. He went to work with a will and has done very good work in completing the Schools. He had the assistance of John Sinclair whenever he required it but for some reason Mr. Harper was not very favorable to him. However the work progressed and was at last completed. The apparent cost has already been submitted to the Department. I shall in a few days be able to show expenditure of the monies advanced on account of these Schools.

Sir,-

I have the honor to present herewith a voucher No. 505 showing the amounts paid by me out of an advance of $537.00 on account of the Peguis Schools which voucher shows a balance on that account of $22.80 as unexpended.

I also enclose therewith a statement shewing the number of Indian receipts for goods supplied by the several merchants at or near Fisher River as far as they have been received to date. A number of these receipts are not yet to hand but have been applied for and may be expected any day. The merchants are a little slow in procuring them owing to the difficulty of reaching the Indians.

I wish to say in connection with these receipts and the orders which were issued by Mr. Farm Instruter Harper that he had no authority at any time from me to issue these orders but did so purely at his own initiative. This has given rise to all the difficulty in collecting receipts.

I also enclose a voucher No. 506 showing that according to my voucher No. 466 I paid on account of the Peguis Schools Mr. Omar Dupont the sum of $100.00
which amount came out of the funds advanced to me for the purpose of erecting these Schools as stated in paragraph one of this letter.

As shown on the voucher I have brought down the amount on hand from Voucher 505, and after deducting that amount from the $100.00 advanced to Mr. Dupont I have entered the balance as due Inspector, namely $77.20.

Two reasons must be given for the expenditure of more money than the $27.00 advanced to me for the purpose of building the Schools.

(1) I directed that the logs be placed down at a point two miles from the North boundary but through interference of the Chief they were placed at about a mile and a quarter and they had to be moved to meet my order.

(2) It was necessary to clear a site for the North School and to do some clearing at the South School and men had to be paid to do this extra work.

I have done the best I could amid many pressing duties and the distance from head-quarters and my frequent absence on the road gave occasion for difficulties that were not anticipated.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Mr. Harbord, the teacher, informed me he had resigned and would be leaving as soon as another teacher arrived. Mr. Harbord is not a strong man and as Mrs. Harbord has been appointed the teacher at Fort Alexander, he wishes to join her there.

NORTH PEGUIS SCHOOL.

I inspected this school November 2nd, and found 18 children present, the roll calling for 24. The attendance has been only fair, but is improving.

The grades range from 1 to 3 and the children appeared well up in their grades. The reading was clear and I believe the children understood what they read. The spelling and arithmetic were good and their writing and exercise books showed care and interest. I believe these children are making fair progress.

The discipline was excellent and the children were the most respectful that I visited. All the children were clean and their clothes were well kept and neat. I might say that the teacher, Mr. Harbord is a very careful man about his own personal appearance and I believe this has its effect upon the children.

I might say that one could feel, on entering this school, a different atmosphere, and at a glance it was evident that the children were receiving the utmost care and attention. Each child had a towel and cup neatly arranged along one side of the school and numbered so that no mistake could be made. The towels, although used, were not dirty.

The teacher's residence at this school is perhaps the best of the three and yet it is a very poor home. Here, again, I think it a mistake to continue repairing, as the home is certainly not suitable, and after continuous repairing, year after year, we really have nothing.

Sir:

Re Well - Peguis North School.

In the Estimates for the present Fiscal Year I placed an item of $200.00 for the purpose of drilling a well at the Peguis North School. This well is essential as, at present, the Teacher at the school has to carry all her water from the river, a distance of one-quarter mile. Water from the river is unfit to drink without being boiled.

I have seen a local well driller and he informs me that he will drill a well and supply all casing for a price of $3.00 per foot. He states that 60 or 70 feet is the maximum distance that he will require to drill to get good water.

May authority be granted to proceed with this work?

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

Referring to your letter of the 3rd. instant, instructing me to have a well drilled at the North Peguis School, as well as at the Peguis Centre School, I may say that when I took this up with the Agent he informed me that he had already received instructions from the Department to proceed with the drilling of a well at the North Peguis School. Of course, I was rather surprised to hear this. I am sorry that the Department has instructed Mr. Templeman to carry out this work without first giving him specific instructions as to how he is to go about it, as he is absolutely incompetent to handle any business, and the matter of drilling wells is one where hundreds of dollars can be wasted if the Department is not safeguarded. Any drilling company will tell you this. We had an experience in drilling wells at Edmonton, where it was found that the drillers purposely passed an excellent supply of water in order to get more drilling, and it is a common practice to do this. I have never delegated any authority to Mr. Templeman without first making it quite clear as to just what was to be done, and then having him submit the whole proposition to me. He has not shown any capacity for business, and as an Agent he is an absolute failure and I, naturally, feel that the spending of money should not be entrusted to him.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir:

Re Well - Peguis North School.

Reference your letter of the 17th September granting authority to drill a well at the above-named school, I beg to advise that this well was completed on the 31st ultimo.

Bedrock was struck at a depth of 36 feet with only a very light flow of surface water. This being about the depth of the old dug well at the Peguis Centre School, where the water was seepage from swamps and only fit for stock, drilling was continued until the impervious layer of rock was penetrated and the porous sandstone struck. This sandstone contains the Artesian water, which originates from Lake Manitoba, the same water as that struck at the wells at the Agency and the Peguis South School. With this well, we are assured of an excellent supply of drinking water at all times. The well casing has been driven in to the bedrock to a depth of 5 feet so that there is no danger of the well filling up with the loose strata above the bed rock. As stated in the attached voucher, the well is 74 feet deep and the cost at $5.00 per feet, inclusive of 41 feet of 6 inch casing supplied by the driller is $222.00. The water in the well is, at present, about 20 feet below the top of the well.

To make use of the water in this well, a pump will be required fitted for 1½ in pipe. The majority of the pumps in the district are B-T Pumps, made by Beatty Bros. of Fergus, Ontario. These pumps give excellent satisfaction and the cost of pump complete with brass cylinder, 20 ft. length of pump rod and 2 - 20 ft. lengths of galv. iron pipe 1½" would be $33. May the necessary authority be granted to supply this pump?

Your obedient servant,

H. Templeman,
Indian Agent.

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK. June 13th, 1929.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report that while at the Fisher River Agency I visited the schools on the Fisher River and Peguis Reserves. Owing to the fact that Saturday, Sunday and Monday were holidays, there were no classes held, but I saw the teachers, buildings, etc., and everything seemed to be going very satisfactorily.

Mr. and Mrs. Tong, at the Fisher River Day School, are doing excellent work. The attendance is good, and the premises are kept in excellent shape. The grounds have been fixed up by the teachers and children, and in a few years, when the trees that have been planted attain a fair size, the place will look beautiful in the summertime. There is a nice lawn all around the school and flower beds have been fixed up.

It is not necessary for me to enlarge upon the buildings at the Peguis North Day School. The school is an old log affair, which is badly dilapidated, and the house is small and cold in the winter. The Church Authorities informed me that they expected new buildings would be erected this year. The teacher, Miss Collen, impresses me as being a very capable woman, and I was informed that she was getting good results with the children.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

At the Peguis
At the Peguis Centre Day School we have new buildings which are very satisfactory in every way and answer the purpose for which they were built, excellently. The teacher, Miss Wright, is also, I believe, doing good work.

At the Peguis South Day School we have a new bungalow, which was built last year, and it looked very nice. The grounds around the school were fixed up by Miss Lee. They are still using the log school. The attendance here is also very encouraging, but I would say that Miss Lee, the teacher, is handicapped by being quite deaf, and I would think that it would be hard for her to hear what the children are saying.

In my opinion the teachers at the day schools on these two reserves are doing excellent work and are giving the children the same chance for an education as what the average child receives at the ordinary country school. As a whole, the children attend quite regularly, and a great change has certainly taken place in the last few years.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

This is taught by Miss N. Collen. There are 31 children on the Register, with an average attendance of about 19. The grades taught are from 1 to 5. I believe Miss Collen is quite a capable teacher, and is bringing the children along very well.

Both the school and teacher's residence here are in very poor shape. The school is an old log building, very cold in winter. The desks are old and dilapidated; in fact some of them have fallen to pieces and the children are sitting on boxes. The teacher's house is small, and very cold in winter. I have reported on this house several times, and some repairs were put on it four or five years ago, which repairs were necessary in order to make it habitable at all. A new set of buildings is badly needed here.

REPORT

re:-

Alleged theft of foot-ball from the North Peguis Indian School, Nuxkik Peguis Indian Reserve, Dallas Dist., Man.

Property of the Dep't. of Indian Affairs.

Further to the report of Reg. No. 10545 Const. Calcraft, C. of the 10th. inst., I hired auto livery and proceeded to the home of John, P. Hamlik, J.P., Hodgson, Man., on the 11th. inst., accompanied by Const. Calcraft of this force, where I obtained Search Warrants to search the premises of Harry Kalyniuk, and Mike Kovenzki of the Dallas District mentioned in the report of Const. Calcraft, of the 10th. inst., and to interview Nurse Brandon at Fisher River, Man., in connection with the above matter.

Upon arrival at Fisher River I interviewed Nurse Brandon who informed me that while she was at the residence of Miss. H. S. Collen, teacher at the North Peguis Indian School on the 4th. inst., at about 6pm, she noticed two men, not Indians, with a team outside the school; one got down from the waggon and kicked something on the road, later picking it up and throwing it in the waggon; the proceeding on their way, she drew the teacher's attention to it and later found out it was the school foot-ball. We then proceeded to the home of Mike Kovenzki in the Dallas Dist. Upon arrival there I was informed by Paul Kovenzki, father of Mike, that his son was away digging Seneca root and would be away for two or three days. I informed his father of my business and he appeared ignorant of the fact that there was a ball missing, a thorough search of the premises produced no results. The same answer described in Const. Calcraft's report, no ball in the yard. His father claimed it was the 5th., that his son was on the Indian Reserve, of course this is nothing to go by as the people in that district would not know one day from the other at times.

I continued the patrol to the farm of Harry Kalyniuk, unfortunately any person coming up to his house can be seen across a muskog for at least half a mile and it is impossible to get a car within three quarters of a mile from the buildings. His buildings are situated on the edge of a thick bush. Upon arrival there I informed Kalyniuk of my business and proceeded to search the premises and adjacent bush. This man appeared to have a knowledge of the matter in question. He admitted stopping his team outside the school on the day in question, his excuse was that he had dropped his whip and Kovenzki had picked it up, from the evidence we have heard this whip still is not able to be believed. We made a thorough search but was unable to locate the ball, although when the bush was being searched he appeared to be uneasy.

I feel confident that this man has the ball concealed somewhere on the premises and the time he had from when he first saw us and the time when we arrived was ample time to throw or place the thing in a secret place, the time would be about four minutes. Mike Stadneychuk.
who lives on the next farm stated when I interviewed him that this man has been seen with a football, he was seen carrying it over from Mike Krevenski's farm about a week ago, this bears out the statement of the two men with the team. I regret very much that we were unable to locate the ball, but I feel confident that Kalyniuk is the guilty party. I was unable to get the value of the ball from Indian Agent Stevenson's file or Miss. Collins who was purchasing for the Dept. at Ottawa and the invoice is there. I would respectfully request that I be furnished with the price if the Dept. desires to take further action in this matter. This is a new ball only been at the school for two weeks, it is No. 5 English hand sewn. Kalyniuk holds a bad reputation in the District he has been in the Police tails on a previous occasion and there has been a certain amount of petty thieving in the District he has been blamed for this. Unfortunately the road to Hodgson is through the Peguis Indian Reserve and there does not appear to be much use of warning him off the reserve as this is the only road from Dallas to Hodgson.

We returned to Hodgson at 10 P.M. of the same date.

REPORT

Man., No. 30-134 N-17
Alleged theft of foot-ball from the North Peguis Indian School, Peguis Indian Reserve, Dallas Dist., Man.
Property of the Dept. of Indian Affairs.

First Report:

Acting on instructions from the R.C.M.P. Hodgson Detachment, I patrolled on the 9th inst. with S.M.2077 to the Indian Agents residence Peguis 1. From that point I proceeded in company with Indian Agent Stevenson by dept auto to the North Peguis School, and Dallas District to make investigations in regard to the above complaint.

Upon arrival at the North Peguis Indian School, I interviewed the teacher Miss M.S. Collen, who stated that the foot-ball, the property of the Dept., which had been carelessly left near the road on the 4th inst., had been picked up by an unknown party who was driving past the school with his team. Miss Collen gave me the undermentioned names, Mrs. G. Mackland and Mr. Pakkoo, who were eyewitnesses of the affair. I later interviewed William Pakkoo, who stated that he was standing at the front door of his house, which is situated in the vicinity of the school; he saw two men coming along the road with a team of hay horses, one horse had a white strip on its face. He saw one man get out of the wagon and kick a foot-ball along the road, later placing it in the wagon, under some hay.

I later interviewed Mrs. G. Mackland who stated that she was standing at the door of her house, which is also situated in the vicinity of the school; she saw one man kick the ball, and later place it in the wagon. Her description of the team was a corroboration of William Pakkoo's description.

I later interviewed William James Flett who stated that he was coming from Hodgson on the evening in question along the road that leads past the school. He also saw a team with two men, and his description of the team was the same given as of the two previous people I interviewed. He also stated that he knew one of these men well as he had worked with him some time previously, and that was the only team he saw on the road that evening. He later gave the men's names as Harry Kalyniuk and Mike Kryvenski, both of Dallas District, to the Indian Agent. Later Mr. Stevenson Indian Agent gave me these two names.

As the Dallas Post Office is located within a couple of miles from the school I proceeded there in order that I may verify the spelling. This information I gave to Corporal Graves on returning to the detachment on the same day.

C. Calcraft

Ottawa, October 16, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, relative to the erection of new out houses at the Peguis South and Peguis North Indian Day Schools. It is noted that you are obtaining an estimate of the cost and will forward same later for the consideration of the Department.

Relative to the old school buildings at both the above schools, I beg to say that they may be given to any Indian who is willing to take them down and remove them from the school lot and level off the site on which they stand. It is noted that the Anglican missionary has spoken to you for these buildings. If you consider that he should have same rather than an Indian, the Department will approve of your making whatever arrangements you consider advisable. In any event, whoever removes the buildings should clear away all rubbish and level the site on which they stand.

Relative to the small frame residence at the North School, you may arrange for the disposal of same, which it is noted is worth approximately $50. If you succeed in disposing of this building to an Indian, you should obtain the purchase price, which should cover the material in the building and the removal of all rubbish and the levelling of the ground on which it is situated. Any amount received for this old residence should be forwarded to the Department for credit to the Receiver General.

I shall be glad if you will arrange to have these old buildings removed at an early date and the ground on which they stand properly levelled.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Re Pasqua North School, Fisher River Agency,

I wish to bring to your attention the condition of the basement in the above school. There is a seepage through the cement walls at this school which occasions considerable trouble and which we are constantly having to pump out, the water coming in to the extent of 2" to 15" according to climatic conditions. It is impossible to entirely remove this water on the level floor, there being no drain to carry it away. I would suggest that we are allowed to sink a pit in one corner of the school basement floor where the water may drain to the one point and be bailed out as necessary with pails or force pump from time to time. To sink such a pit of cement and a cover for the pit would cost approximately twenty-two to twenty-five dollars.

Can you give us authority to make this expenditure and we will do same during the winter before the spring waters will create a further flooded condition?

Your obedient servant,

C. H. Laverier,
Indian Agent

REGINA, SASK., October 20th, 1931.

Sir:

In reply to Department letter of September 8th, No. 136-6-5, I beg to say that the teacher at the Peguis North Day School, Miss Collen, has agreed to undertake the preparation of a mid-day meal for the pupils, and a supply of groceries has been ordered and sent to Miss Collen.

Miss Collen requests that tables and benches be supplied, and I shall be glad to receive authority to expend about $20.00 for this purpose. The necessary lumber could be purchased locally and a handy Indian could do the work.

I regret to inform you that Miss Wright, teacher at the South Day School, declines to prepare the meal for her 47 pupils without assistance. Miss Wright was not asked to prepare the meal herself; she was asked to supervise the preparation of the meal by the older girls, which she might well do, and it seems to me that it would be in order to inform Miss Wright that she is expected to do this. This would be a splendid training for the girls, and to have an untrained Indian woman come in to do this work would be absurd. With your permission I will instruct Miss Wright that she is expected to oversee this work as part of her duties.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter 1136-4-5 of Nov 16/33. With reference to your letter of Sept 23rd I must acknowledge that I construed your letter to mean $40.00 for each school and I based my construing on the fact that a grant of $50.00 had been made to the two roomed school at Fisher River. I presumed that the sum of $40.00 for each of the Peguis schools was a fair amount in comparison, especially as there are in attendance in most of the Peguis Schools, more than 50% of the attendance of Fisher River. The amounts supplied to these respective schools is not excessive if a meal is to be given. This question, in mind is a doubtful necessity.

Inspectors have previously recommended that these mid-day meals be provided and I have carried on under the assumption that it was the wish of the Dept. to serve a mid-day meal in the schools. The sum of $40.00 as suggested by you would be just about sufficient to supply cocoa and nothing else. If it is your desire, I will instruct the teachers of these schools, that in the future they should not ask for anything other than that commodity.

Regretting my action in the matter, I am,

Your obedient servant,

G. A. Lavender,
Indian Agent

Dear Sir:

Reference to your letter 136-4-5 dated July 7/34, I beg to submit an estimate covering the repairs required at the Peguis North, Centre and South Indian Day Schools.

PEGUIS NORTH SCHOOL
Considerable damage has been done to the plaster on the walls of this school and I would estimate that the cost to put same in good condition would be $15.00. The interior of this school should also be painted. This would entail an expenditure for five gallons of paint at approximately $4.00 per gallon, $20.00. The labor would cost approximately $15.00. Considerable carpenter work is needed and I would estimate that $10.00 would cover this service. A total of $60.00 will be needed for the Peguis North School.

PEGUIS CENTRE SCHOOL
Interior painting is required with paint and labor as stated above $35.00 and a further $10.00 for carpenter repairs. At this school an appropriation is also needed for the cleaning out of the well and installing the pump. For this school therefore, an appropriation of $70.00 is required for upkeep of buildings and equipment.

PEGUIS SOUTH SCHOOL
Interior painting is required at an approximate cost of $25.00, repairs to desks and carpenter work a further $15.00 would be required. The estimate, therefore, for this school for upkeep would be $50.00.

If these amounts are passed I would appreciate a reply as early as possible that the work may be completed before school opens in September.

Your obedient servant,

G. G. Lavender,
Indian Agent

Extract from Inspector Hamilton's report on the Peguis North Indian Day School dated March 6, 1941:

Some plaster is off one side of the room, and when possible, this should be repaired. It is difficult in these outlying districts to secure a competent man to do this work. The stove is also warped beyond repair and is unsafe. A new stove should be provided.
Ottawa,
March 13, 1941.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his inspection of the Peguis North School Inspector Hamilton states that the plaster is off one side of the room. I understand it is difficult to secure a competent man to repair this plaster but whenever you can secure a man for the purpose you should have the necessary work done.

Inspector Hamilton also states that the stove is warped and is unsafe. Please let me have definite information regarding the type of stove required at this school. Do you think the present stove will last for the present winter?

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. F.J. Clarke,
Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Man.
Dear Sir,

Re Peguis North School.

With reference your letter 136-4-5 dated March 13th, regarding condition of plaster and stove by Mr Inspector Hamilton and your request make and kind of stove, the stove should be replaced next fall the present will do this spring. Stove required should take a four foot cordwood length of the barrel type if one supplied which should be in the fall before winter set in, regarding the plaster am unable to state cost of replastering as there are no competent men up in this district, unless the Dept decide to put on plaster board and this could be done by Indians if the Department consider putting on plaster board would recommend it be done during the summer vacation,

Your obedient servant.

F. J. Clarke
Indian Agent.

EXTRACT FROM REQUISITION DATED MAY 25th, 1945.
FROM THE TEACHER OF THE NORTH REGUIS INDIAN
DAY SCHOOL. ORIGINAL ON FILE # 136-4-4

The teacher states:

One of the schoolroom doors needs a new lock.

Something will have to be done re accommodation for the pupils. Serious congestion has arisen since the registration for children's allowance.

There are desks for 20 pupils. I have 50 enrolled, 42 Treaty and 8 Non-treaty. The Non-treaty have been attending regularly the whole year and there is no other school.
Ottawa, June 14, 1945.

Mr. F. J. Clarke, Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Man.

On a requisition recently received from the teacher of the North Peguis Indian Day School, there is a request for a new lock for one of the doors. You may purchase this.

The teacher also refers, on the requisition, to the necessity for new desks. She states that there is an enrolment of 50, of which 42 are Treaty Indian children, and that there are only 20 desks in the school.

Is there space in this classroom for additional desks? I am not certain to what she refers when she mentions non-Treaty, but I presume she means half-breeds. If accommodation is limited, the Treaty Indian children should receive first consideration. If there is room in the school for 42 desks, please let me know the sizes of the desks required, in order that we may place an order for the additional 22. With the granting of family allowances, it is presumed that the attendance at the day schools will increase. You have already received specific instructions regarding the action that must be taken in regard to family allowances when children do not attend school regularly. Desks are made in three sizes - large, medium and small. You should let me know the number of each size of these that is necessary.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division
INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH. DEPT MINES & RESOURCES. OTTAWA. CANADA.

In replying to your letter of June 14th file 136-4-5 in regard to additional Desks for the North Peguis School, we advise that there is very little room for any additional desks without crowding. What is really needed is another room, or an addition to the present building, as this is about central for this North End vicinity. The children at present are using benches.

The services of another teacher would be required in the event of another room, and the two teachers could live in the present Teachers Residence.

There are attending at present, 8 Non-Treaty of whom 7 are Half-Breeds and the other a son of the Pentecostal Minister. There is no Provincial School that these children could attend.

The Desks that would be required would be for the smaller children, who by reason of the Family Allowances are going to school. The starting age being 6 instead of the usual 7 years.

The Teacher could, without too much crowding, put in another 5 or 6 desks which should be small.

FJC/OT

F J Clarke, Indian Agent
Ottawa, June 29, 1945.

Mr. F. J. Clarke, Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Man.

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, with reference to the request for desks for the Peguis North School. We will arrange to order six small size single desks.

We have no funds provided in the current year's appropriation for an addition to the school or the erection of another room.

In the third paragraph of your letter you refer to 8 children for whom this Department has no responsibility with regard to education. The education of the children you mention is a provincial responsibility, and, as stated in my letter of the 14th instant, if the accommodation is limited, these children should not be allowed to attend the school during the academic year 1945-46.

I am aware that the Family Allowance Act provides for children to attend school at 6 years of age. However, if you will refer to Section 10 (1) of the Indian Act, you will note that the age for compulsory attendance of Indian children at school is 7 years, and it is our intention to adhere to the Indian Act in this particular regard.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith reports of my annual inspection of Peguis and Fisher River Schools.

Since payments of Family Allowances have come into effect, the three schools on Peguis Reserve are badly overcrowded, the one having an enrolment of 72 where 40 could conveniently be accommodated. These three schools have no transom windows nor other ventilation system.

Would it be possible to have transom windows installed as soon as possible?

Yours truly,

C.J. Muller.
Ottawa, 27th December, 1945.

Mr. P.G. Lazenby, Indian Agent, Hodgson, Manitoba.

In connection with the Peguis North Day School, Inspector Muller also suggests installing of transom windows and you may have the work done during the Christmas holidays. He stated, in addition, repairs are needed to desks and cupboards. Please have this work done also.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
We acknowledge your letter of December 27th last file 136-4-5 in regard to North School in connection with Mr Muller's report.

As suggested, we are having the desks and cupboards repaired, and also, a transom installed when we can get a carpenter to do the work.

We might add that, we may be able to procure the North W.A. Church Hall for a second room to alleviate the pressure of attendance at North Peguis. Some minor repairs are necessary to this hall, such as glass, door, putty etc. The rental would be $15.00 per month.

The W.A. of the Anglican Church have good sized halls close to each of our Peguis Schools and are willing to rent them to the Department, temporarily for $15.00 per month.
