It will be noted from the 1948-49 Estimates for this agency on Page 3 - SCHOOLS, provision has been made for the painting of the three Day Schools on Peguis reserve and the teachers' residences attached thereto, and the Large Fisher River Day School. The cost of painting the three Peguis schools and residences was estimated at $370.00 each, and the cost of painting the Fisher River School, at $1,000.00.

We have had a Painter and Decorator here, a Mr. A.W. Wadelius of 110 Young Street, Winnipeg to look over these buildings and give estimates on the cost of this work.

We have now received Mr. Wadelius' written quotations, which are, as per attached copies of the originals, on his own letterheads. These quotations are somewhat higher than estimated, which is no doubt due to the increase in cost of both labour and materials.

All these school and residences are badly in need of painting, and it would be appreciated if the Department would approve of the work being done during the coming summer holidays.

P.G. Lazenby,
Sup't: Fisher River Agency.
June 1st, 1948.

Mr. P.G. Lazenby, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Hodgson, Manitoba.

We have your letter of the 22nd ultimo with reference to painting the three day schools on the Peguis Reserve and also the Fisher River School.

It is noted in the case of the three Peguis Schools the firm requests $450.00 for material and in the case of the Fisher River School, $375.00. I am inclined to feel that we could save some money by purchasing the paint ourselves and in that event I presume that the quotation for labour would be according to the amount mentioned in the tender.

You might let me have a requisition for the paint required. We would then be in a position to decide if the saving would be effective.

It is doubtful if we can authorize the expenditure required for all four schools and if we have to delay the painting of one of them we would like to know at which school the painting could be delayed until next year.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter 136-4-5 (E 1) of June 1st., we attach hereto a Requisition covering paint and material required for the three Peguis and Fisher River Schools. Peguis North Indian Day School
Opening of Second Classroom.

This will confirm the fact that we are prepared to open a second classroom at the Peguis North Indian Day School. I note that the Indians are prepared through the W.A. to put this hall in first class shape and rent it to us at $26. per month.

I also understand that the only expenditure involved will be this rental fee and that the Indians will carry out the necessary repairs.

With regard to the blackboards, please find attached a standard letter sent in this regard. It is presumed that you can make the necessary purchase of masonite in Hodgson and that you can order the blackboard paint immediately.

I understand that you will be forwarding shortly, a requisition for the desks. Be sure to indicate the number of small, medium and large required.
You might also consider, in view of the fact that you will have a large number of primary children, of building a large kindergarten table or tables. You are aware, that modern educational practice favours the use of these tables for primary classes rather than the use of individual desks. It is presumed that you could have these tables made locally by one of the Indians on the Reserve. I would suggest that they be made 23" high with room for three children on either side and one at each end.

They could be covered with either masonite or battleship linoleum. We can then order kindergarten chairs from one of the standard school supply companies for use with these tables.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter No 347989/5 of the 21st instant in reference to the application of the Teachers of the Peguis Schools for living quarters.

I respectfully recommend that living quarters be provided them; it being quite true that there is no suitable accommodation for them upon the reserve.

I would recommend that separate houses be erected; these can be built at any time with lumber at a cost of about $200.00 each. I enclose a sketch of a small building suitable for the purpose submitted by Mr Taylor.

your obedient servant

Ottawa, January 17, 1931.

Sir:

I have your 203-LIA of the 5th instant, regarding the furnishings required for the new bungalow at the Peguis North Indian Day School.

In this connection I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following:

- Heater - McClary's air tight,
- 4 Wood dining chairs,
- 1 Rocking chair (arm),
- 1 Congoleum mat, 15' x 9', for living room,
- 2 Carpet rugs for living room,
- 2 Washable mats for bedrooms,
- 1 Metal flour bin for 100 lbs. flour,
- 1 Bed with mattress and pillows (48" wide),
- 1 Extension couch for second room,
- 1 Kitchen range (small not more than 48" x 29"),
- 1 Table (48" x 30"),
- 1 Sheet of tin for behind heater.

The heater and kitchen range should be properly installed, and while serviceable furnishings should be obtained, it is not intended that any expensive articles be supplied.

Regarding the request for a drop leaf writing desk and fernery, with metal tray, I have to say that the Department does not usually supply this type of equipment in furnishing teachers' living quarters, and it is considered that it is not necessary to purchase these two items at the present time.

Your obedient servant,

We are attaching hereto a Requisition covering furniture and equipment required at the Peguis #4 School Residence. In making up this requisition, we have been guided by the suggested scale of issue for furniture for a standard One-Room Indian Day School Residence.

The stove (Kitchen Range) is in bad shape and should be re-placed as soon as possible. It is burnt out, allowing ashes to go into the baking oven. The door is also broken. It is hoped this item will be allowed to stand.

The rooms in this School residence are very dirty and we have attached a requisition covering Caseine paint (FLITE) a washable paint. We believe we can get an Indian woman to do the work, as its much the same as whitewashing. The total expenditure in this connection including the material should not be over $37.50. If this work is approved, we would appreciate receiving an accountable advance of $25.00 to cover the work.

Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Lake Winnipeg Inspectorate,
Winnipeg, Man., Nov. 6, 1911.

Sir,

The South school has been placed in charge of a young divinity student of the Church of England who will open the school forthwith. His appointment dates from the first of October although he has been working as carpenter's assistant during that month. This school was not completed as rapidly as the North school, but was ready for occupation on the 4th of November. The delay being occasioned by the burning of lime and the time necessary to plaster the school after that was done.

The name of the teacher of the South school is H.J. Francis, a well educated young man of excellent character. I hope the Department will see its way to pay him at the rate of $400.00 per year. He left a salary of $60.00 per month here to go to that work and has only agreed to remain for six months, but if he likes the work may continue with the permission of the Department for an indefinite period.

I have the honour to be

Your obedient servant,

John Semmens,

The Secretary, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.
Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant in which you state that the South Peguis School has been placed in charge of Mr. H. J. Francis, a young divinity student.

In reply I beg to say that this appointment is satisfactory and a salary of $400.00 per annum will be allowed to date from the 1st of October, last. Returns showing the attendance, etc., should be forwarded by the teacher and you will be kind enough to give him the necessary instructions. You should also impress upon him the necessity for teaching calisthenics and hygiene and some copies of the text books on these subjects will be sent you for this school. These latter remarks apply also to the North School.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. J. Sommers,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

I have to acknowledge your letter No 398424/1 dated September 11th, in reply beg to say that I have placed myself in communication with Archbishop Matheson and have asked that a nomination of a suitable person be made for this position by him at as early a date as possible, in the meantime I will look out and find some if I can.

Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Sir,— I beg to notify the Department that H J Francis teacher of the South Peguis School sent in his resignation to Mr Inspector Bunn and gave up his duties on the 30th of September, not hearing from Mr Bunn I appointed Andrew McPherson to take charge of this school, he is an Indian of this band and has a fair education and I think will get along, and as this was the wish of the people at that end of the reserve I think perhaps they will now be more interested in sending their children to School.

Your Obedient Servant,

Indian Agent,
Fisher River Agency.

The Secretary,
Department Of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, October 16, 1912.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo advising the Department that you have placed Andrew McPherson, an Indian, in charge of the South Peguis School.

In reply I beg to say that this appointment is approved, but on the understanding that it is only temporary and that Mr. McPherson will give up the position when a qualified teacher is available. In the meantime he will be paid at the rate of $300.00 per annum. The Department is communicating with the church authorities with a view to securing a qualified teacher.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Secretary.

David Fraser, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Man.

The Department wishes to secure a competent teacher for this school and I have to ask you to be good enough to consult with the church authorities with this object in view and report.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Secretary.

John R. Bunn, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

LAKE WINNIPEG INSPECTORATE

WINNIPEG, MAN., 15th January 1913.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Sir,

I am today in receipt of a letter from His Grace Archbishop Matheson, which has reference to a suitable teacher for South Peguis Day School, this is the outcome of somewhat lengthened negotiation to secure a suitable teacher for this School as intimated in your letter number and date above quoted. I am pleased to recommend for favorable consideration the re-appointment of Mr. H. Francis, his services, I have found, were very acceptable during his previous occupancy of this position, and his resignation was on account of some friction between himself and late Agent Fraser, of a personal nature.

Mr. Francis will expect salary at the rate of $500.00 per year, and I think he is worth it; he is a careful, pains-taking and energetic man, with good habits of life.

I have the honor to be

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Copy of Archbishop Matheson's letter inclosed.
Bishop's Court,
Winnipeg, Man.

My Dear Mr Bunn,

I understand from Mr Saunderson that Mr Francis is willing to resume charge of the School he had at Peguis. I am very much pleased to hear this and will be glad to see him go back if the Department is agreeable. Some day I would like to have a chat with you about establishing an Improved School on the New Reserve.

With kind regards,

Yours most sincerely,

(signed) S.P. Rupert's Land.
Ottawa, February 1st, 1917.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th inst., and in reply beg to say that the Department will be pleased to have Mr. Francis resume charge of the South Peguis Day School as soon as possible and will pay him from the date that he takes charge at the rate of $500.00 per annum.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J.R. Bunn, Esq.,

Sir:

I enclose herewith copy of letter received from Mr. Packer, teacher at the South Peguis School, in which he tenders his resignation, asking for immediate leave of absence and permission to have Mrs. Packer act as substitute until such time as a new teacher is appointed.

I beg to recommend that his resignation be accepted and that the requested leave of absence be granted and permission to have Mrs. Packer substitute for him be approved. Mrs. Packer is not a qualified teacher but her services would be satisfactory for the period mentioned, namely two months.

Mr. Packer's services as teacher have been satisfactory and his reason for leaving the position is that, he has obtained employment with his brother, who is a Building Contractor in Winnipeg. With reference to second paragraph of his letter, I spoke to him with reference to this and he informed me that his employment would not carry him through the winter months and it was his intention, should the Department approve, to return and carry on school until March 31, 1929.

I do not think that this would be a satisfactory arrangement and would recommend that a new teacher be appointed to take over school on or about November 1, 1928. The new residence, now under construction, will not be ready much before that date and the old building is not a habitable place, especially for a person new to the Reserve.

Your obedient servant,

H. Templeman,

Dear Doctor McGill:

The teacher in charge here is Miss M.J. Lavender. She is a qualified teacher and doing fair work. The roll calls for 33 pupils, 17 boys and 16 girls. The grades range from 1 to 5.

The attendance at this school is poor. A van operates, hauling the children a distance of from six to eight miles. The pupils hauled have not been attending regularly, and often only 6 or 7 arrive in the van. Unless better attendance is obtained, it might be more economical for the Department to give a small grant to the white school at Hodgson where the Indian children from the extreme south end of the reserve could attend. This would not interfere with the south school as it would leave an enrolment of around 20 pupils, and no doubt some could be transferred from the Centre Peguis School. I have advised Mr. Lavender that it might be well to have the Mounted Police make a check-up on the truant children. A year or two ago the police made regular inspection trips, with the result that the school attendance was much better.

It will be noted that the children are all in the lower grades at this school. They speak out well and are not timid or shy. The exercise books were clean and the work neatly set out.

I submit the following report on the Peguis Indian Day Schools inspected during the week of October 16th, 1944.

South Peguis Indian Day School

Mrs. Hamrlik is in charge. She is a qualified teacher and greatly interested in her work. There are thirty-four pupils enrolled, with an average attendance of around twenty-six. The grades are as follows:

Grade 1 - 17
" 2 - 6
" 3 - 6
" 4 - 4
" 5 - 1

The pupils appear to enjoy their work and I believe they are making good progress.

Mrs. Hamrlik expects when all the Indians are back to have an enrolment of from 40 to 50. There are only seats enough for 36 pupils. Either more seats should be provided or in their place a table with six chairs.

The classroom was clean, tidy and well aired. It has recently been painted inside and this has made a vast improvement. The exterior was painted last year.

The residence needs interior cleaning. The material for the walls is on hand and Mrs. Hamrlik intends to do the work. Her appointment came rather late and up until now the classroom has claimed her full attention.
Centre Peguis Indian Day School

Miss Alice Clarke is in charge at this point. She too is a qualified teacher and I consider she is doing very excellent work.

The roll calls for thirty-two pupils and I found twenty present. The average for September was 19.4. The grades are as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| 1     | 17     |
| 2     | 5      |
| 3     | 3      |
| 4     | 1      |
| 5     | 2      |
| 7     | 4      |

The work seen was well done, and the pupils appeared keenly interested.

The interior of the classroom had just been painted. The work was well done; and the light shades used have made the room very attractive.

The residence was put on a new foundation a year ago and is in good condition.

North Peguis Indian Day School

There are thirty-four children enrolled. Miss Eaton is in charge. She is an excellent teacher and appears greatly admired by the pupils. I found eighteen present and the average attendance for September was 17.7. The grades were arranged as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| 1     | 17     |
| 2     | 2      |
| 3     | 8      |
| 4     | 1      |
| 5     | 5      |
| 6     | 1      |

The children were clean and neatly dressed. The work examined was good and the children are making fair progress.

This classroom has also been re-decorated and the painting has made a wonderful change.
The school residence is in good repair. I found some water in the basement; but this no doubt is due to the excessive heavy rains during the late summer and fall. Miss Eaton stated this is the first showing of water since the foundation was fixed over a year ago. She thinks the small amount accumulated will shortly disappear.

The yards were tidy and the fences in good repair.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Mr. B.F. Neary's letter, File 136-5-1 (W.T.L.) dated the 13th instant, and in reply, to advise that when the Elkhorn Residential School Bus came to Hodgson, to pick up the pupils returning to that school after the holidays, I was introduced to Miss Annabella Stranger, and in talking with her, I mentioned to her that she would no doubt be taking over her duties as teacher on the Peguis reserve. Miss Stranger then told me that the Rev. Mr. Smith, the local Anglican missionary on Peguis reserve, had informed her that she was to go to teach at the Sioux Lookout Residential School. A few days later, Miss Stranger met me in Hodgson, and asked me if I had received a letter from Dr. Alderwood, and I told her that I had not. She then stated that she had received a telegram from Dr. Alderwood, advising her that she was to go to teach at Sioux Lookout, and that he was writing me. However, to date, I have received no communication from any source regarding the sending of Miss Stranger to Sioux Lookout. Miss Stranger has gone to Sioux Lookout, and Miss Kathleen Jeffrey is teaching alone at South Peguis School, and has 53 pupils.

I had been under the impression that I had already advised the Department of the foregoing, but on checking, I find that I had mentioned the matter to Inspector Hamilton, in a letter to him regarding the proposal he made, to try for authority to build a lean-to on the school for a temporary teacher's residence, provided he was able to procure the materials.

The sending of Miss Stranger to Sioux Lookout, after her nomination by the Archbishop of Rupert's Land, and the Department's approval, that she teach at Peguis Reserve, seems rather out of order, especially when no reference of any sort has been made to
this office. Apparently the Department also has not been advised in the matter, and it would appear that some of the Anglican Church officials are working at cross purposes in the matter of the appointing of teachers. We are four teachers short for the three Peguis Schools. There is one teacher at North school, and one at the South school, and the Centre school remains closed.

I beg to report as follows regarding Day School Teachers at the day schools in this agency, for the school year beginning 1st September 1947:

PEGUIS SOUTH SCHOOL. Miss Kathleen Jeffrey, the present teacher advises that she will be returning to teach this school next year. However, it would be advisable to procure an extra teacher for this school if at all possible, so that the pupils may be divided, half being taught in the Church Hall as formerly proposed, as there are over 60 pupils on the roll and the school is much overcrowded. The two teachers could occupy the teacher's residence. The Church Hall is about a half mile from the residence.

PEGUIS NORTH SCHOOL. Miss Una McDonald, the present teacher will be returning to teach this school next year. This school also should be divided, and an extra teacher procured. Half the pupils could be taught in the Church Hall, which is near the school, and both teachers could occupy the residence.

PEGUIS CENTRE SCHOOL. As the Department is aware, this school has been closed for over a year. The Agency Clerk and his family occupy the teacher's residence. As mentioned in previous letters, it had been hoped that a new Clerk's House would be built this summer, and this school opened again on September 1st next. If this can be done, a teacher should be engaged for this school. If this cannot be done, a teacher

INFORMATION FOR THE EMPLOYEE

8. Dependents. Taxpayers may claim as dependents only—

(1) A person wholly dependent on the taxpayer for support and of whom the taxpayer was immediately before such person attained the age of twenty-one years did have, in law or in fact, the custody and control.

(2) Sons, daughters, stepsons, illegitimate sons and daughters or sons-in-law or daughters-in-law, brothers and sisters or brothers-in-law or sisters-in-law, and grandchildren, if under eighteen years of age or over eighteen but twenty-one and attending school or over eighteen years of age and incapable of self-support.

(3) Parents, grandparents, parents-in-law or grandparent-in-law, if wholly dependent on the taxpayer for self-support.

(4) A daughter or sister under twenty-one years of age training as a nurse in a public or provincial licensed private hospital.

9. If Child Under 16 Years and Not Registrable for Family Allowances. A taxpayer may claim an exemption of only $100 for a wholly dependent child that he might have been registrable under The Family Allowances Act, 1944, had an allowance under the said Act was or might have been paid in respect of the last month of the taxation year within which a few months' event occurred and 16 years of age may be registered and receive payments under The Family Allowances Act. Therefore, Form T.D.I. provides that only the $100 exemption may be claimed for a child under 16 years of age in Item 5 as having been born after November 1941.

There are isolated cases, however, of children under 16 years of age who are not registrable for family allowances. An employee supporting a dependent child is entitled to claim the $300 exemption for tax deduction purposes. Therefore, an employer receiving a T.D.I form in which an employee claims the $300 exemption for a child under 16 years of age and tax deductions accordingly made must immediately refer the T.D.I form to the District Inspector of Income Tax for confirmation, accompanied by a declaration signed by the employee outlining the facts which substantiate his claim that he is the sole support of a child who is not eligible for registration under The Family Allowances Act.

10. If Income of Spouse in Excess of $750. A taxpayer is not entitled to claim married status if his (her) spouse will have an income of more than $750 during the calendar year. If the spouse's income has been more than $250 but not more than $750, the exemption permitted for married status must be reduced by the amount by which the income of the spouse will exceed $250. If the spouse's income will be less than $600, then $350 should be entered in Item 6(B) (2) (i.e., $600 less $250). If the spouse's own income for the calendar year will be no more than $250, Item 6(B) (2) will be left blank and the full marital exemption of $750 will be claimed in Item 6(B) (3).

11. "Self-contained Domestic Establishment" means a dwelling house, apartment, or other similar place of residence, containing at least two bedrooms, in which residence amongst other things the taxpayer as a general rule sleeps and has his meals prepared and served. (See Item 10.)

12. Change in Status or Dependents. If during the year any change occurs in the status or dependents of an employee, the employee must complete and file with his employer an amended Form T.D.I.

13. Effect of Failure to File Form T.D.I. In cases where Form T.D.I. (Revised for Jan. 1947) is not properly filed with the employer, deductions from all salaries or wages paid on or after January 1st, 1947 must be made as if the employee were a single person without dependents even though the employee may have filed a previous Form T.D.I. Single persons without dependents need not file this form.

14. Filing of Income Tax Returns. In addition to filing this form you must file your Income Tax Return Form T.1 Special or T.1 General for the calendar year on or before 30th April of the following year.

INSTRUCTIONS TO THE EMPLOYER

15. If Form T.D.I Not Filed By Employee. Any employee who fails to file a completed Form T.D.I. (Revised for Jan. 1947) must be regarded for tax deduction purposes as a single person without dependents and deductions made as per column I in the Table of Income Tax Deductions (1947).

16. Employer to Scrutinize Claims by Single Person for Married Status. The inclusion of a "Self-contained Domestic Establishment" condition in Item 11 indicates clearly that a taxpayer is not entitled to claim Married Status by reason of supporting a dependent therein unless the dependent actually lives there and the taxpayer therefore, employers are instructed to check the address shown under Item 4(B) or 4(D) with the taxpayer's own address. Item 4(B) should show where he is actually living at the time of making the declaration and in every case where the addresses are not the same the employer must make deductions as if the taxpayer were a single person, with or without dependents as the case may be.

17. Employer's Responsibility Regarding Form T.D.I. The employer will have regard to the instructions contained in Item 16 above will check the employee's computations of the total exemptions in Item 6 and will otherwise make certain that the form is fully completed. He may also delete as a dependent any name in the name list of persons whom the employee has already listed in Item 4 unless the claim for married status came within paragraph (B) thereof. If the employer has reason to believe that any of the information on the form is incorrect or false he will not act upon the declaration until the employee has made the appropriate confirmation or correction. In case of doubt, the matter should be referred to the District Inspector of Income Tax.

18. Action upon Receipt of Amended Form T.D.I. during Currency of Year. Employees are required to file an amended Form T.D.I. if any change occurs in their status or dependents. The employer should give immediate effect to a change from 'Single' status to 'Married' status and to an increase in the number of dependents. A change from 'Married' status to 'Single' status (e.g. where the employee becomes a widow) should not be made effective until the first pay period in the next calendar year because the employee will not be entitled to claim Married Status for the whole of the calendar year in which the change took place. Similarly, a decrease in the number of dependents should not generally require a change in the deductions until the following calendar year. One important exception due to the provision that a taxpayer may not claim as a dependent any person whose own income in excess of $400 during the calendar year. If, for example, a person previously supported by an employee and was claimed as a dependent on Form T.D.I takes up employment from another employer during the calendar year, immediate effect should be given to the amended form T.D.I as otherwise the employee will be left with a substantial balance of tax to pay with his return on Form T.1 Special or T.1 General.

19. Further Information or Forms with respect to deduction of tax may be obtained from any District Inspector of Income Tax.

20. Completed Forms T.D.I must be kept on File by the employer in order that they may be available at all times for payroll inspection by officers of the Taxation Division.

As I discussed with you during your recent visit to Ottawa, we are faced with two alternatives in providing the needed educational facilities for this section of the Fisher River Agency:

(1) The erection of 3 one-room schools at No. 2, No. 3 and No. 4 sites. These would be one-room schools with attached teachers' residences and would be built immediately adjacent to the present buildings. This would provide 3 two-room schools.

(2) The erection of a three-room school near the agency residence. This would involve the transportation of the older children from the No. 2 School and the No. 4 School to a consolidated school, daily. It is the preferable plan from an educational point of view but it has the following disadvantages:

(a) The roads must be in good condition throughout the academic year, to ensure bus trips every day.

(b) The cost of either maintaining our own school bus
or hiring a school bus would be an expensive item.

(e) If the Department were to purchase a bus, it would be necessary to employ a full-time caretaker-chauffeur. It is difficult to get authority for the purchase of a school bus from the Treasury Board and we prefer contracting locally for such transportation services.

To summarize, it would be preferable to build a consolidated school but the relatively slight advantages from this procedure would seem to be outweighed by the disadvantages. As we will have to make our plans for these buildings in the near future, a final decision must be reached soon. Peguis Indian Day Schools.

Reference your 203-11AG of April 28th.

We are agreed concerning the erection of three single school rooms, but we do not feel that we should add to the present buildings. I have discussed this matter with both the Supervisor of Vocational Training and the Educational Survey Officer, and we are agreed for the following reasons:

1. The present school buildings were erected in 1928, and are therefore, now twenty-one years of age. We would be adding to a building now past "middle age". Our Engineers and Architects do not recommend that this be done to a permanent building.

2. From our experience at Big Eddy, it is very difficult to add a furnace to a building which was not designed to receive one. It would be necessary to have a blower to force the hot air from the furnace to the two classrooms. A gravity feed furnace would not draw the hot air to the far ends of the two classrooms. The teachers or the children at the far ends of the classrooms would definitely not be warm enough in the winter time.
3. The teacherages, while satisfactory for one teacher and possibly, a member of his or her family, may be rather small for two teachers unless they happened to be friends.

Therefore, we feel that the following action is indicated:

1. The building of three one-room schools as per plan 888 at Peguis No. 2, 3 and 4 schools.

2. The insulation of the present buildings with 3" battens on the ceiling. Where the walls of the existing schools require it, insulate them with insul brick. We could use insul brick on the outside of the new classrooms, and this would make them very similar in appearance.

We still have an open mind about the four-room school, but feel that the decision to erect three separate buildings will probably be more advisable to suit our needs for at least the next ten years.

We would be pleased to have your comments concerning the remarks made above.

Bernard Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

June 24, 1949.

Mr. W. S. Patterson,
Public School Inspector,
Eriksdale, Manitoba.

Indian Schools in the Fisher River Agency.

I have read with much interest your reports on the schools on the Peguis and Fisher River reserves. As you are aware, we are trying to follow a definite building program which will eventually provide complete educational facilities for all the Indian children on these reserves. The Murdoch School has been completed and also the Peguis No. 1 School.

Tenders have been called for the construction of extra classroom units at Peguis No. 2, No. 3 and No. 4 Schools.

When I visited these reserves with Mr. Davis, our Regional Supervisor, last year, I reviewed with him the advisability of appointing a supervising principal for all these schools from Fisher River down to Peguis No. 1. This would place the following classrooms under more effective organization and provide a uniform direction of school activities for the following classrooms:

| Location     | Rooms |
|--------------|-------|
| Fisher River | 2     |
| Murdoch      | 1     |
| Peguis No. 4 | 2     |
| Peguis No. 3 | 2     |
| Peguis No. 2 | 2     |
| Peguis No. 1 | 1     |

Total: 10 rooms

As a beginning I suggested that we appoint one of the senior and experienced teachers to be supervising principal at a correspondingly
higher rate of salary. This principal would teach in one of the schools and would be absent from his classroom one or possibly two afternoons a week to visit the other rooms and co-ordinate the classroom activities therein. We would naturally pay for his mileage on these trips.

We have followed this procedure in other reserves with much success. The Indian Superintendent has a supervising principal who not only helps him with building repairs, maintenance, etc., but who co-ordinates all educational activities and who is responsible to him for such matters as janitor supplies, classroom supplies, etc.

I do appreciate the interest which you have shown in these schools and would therefore be glad to have your comments concerning the feasibility of the above program and also your views in regard to the appointment to this position of Mr. T. W. Emerson. I was favourably impressed during my short visit to this school and I also have noted your comments concerning him on your last Inspector's report. His enthusiasm and educational interest will, I hope, help to put Indian education on these reserves on a proper footing.

You will note that I have written this letter under confidential heading and you can rest assured your reply will receive the same treatment here.

A copy of this letter is being sent to our Regional Supervisor in Winnipeg as he is keenly interested in these proposals.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Sir:

We are taking up with His Grace the Archbishop of Rupert's Land the question of obtaining a suitable teacher to succeed Mr. Packer on the date mentioned.

You will be good enough to inform Mr. Packer of the acceptance of his resignation and also to inform Mrs. Packer that she may act as substitute until November 1st, next.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

The salary allowed her will be at the same rate as was to be allowed if she taught at the South School, viz., $90 per teaching month.

Please advise the Department of the date on which Miss Wright begins duties at the Centre School.

We are informed by His Grace that he expects within a few days to nominate a teacher for the Peguis South School.

Sir,

Transportation of Children to Peguis South School.

On account of impassability of roads transportation of pupils to the Peguis South school by sleigh ceased on March 21st past. Up until recently the roads have still been impassable on the South Boundary of the Reserve on account of overflow of ditches rendering it difficult for a loaded wheel conveyance to travel.

I beg to recommend that the transportation of pupils to the Peguis South School be continued during the present fiscal year and, in this connection, beg to request authority to ask for tenders for this work for a period ending November 30th, 1928. After that date, hauling will be done by sleighs and a new tender for this work up until March 31st, 1929 should be requested. May authority also be granted to ask for tenders for this period at the expiration of transportation on wheels on October 31, 1928?

In connection with transportation on wheels, I beg to advise that no person or Indian in the vicinity is possessed of a suitable vehicle and it would be necessary for the department to supply a light spring wagon with top frame and canvas cover for wet weather. I am enclosing herewith a copy of Approved Form of Contract between School District and Van Driver as in use by Provincial School Districts and would refer you to paragraph 2 thereof which allows that the School District supplies the conveyance, the Contractor, vide para. 1, supplying horses, harness, robes, etc.

I beg to recommend that the department supply the necessary conveyance, the cost of which should not exceed $150. I have made no enquiries as to the cost of such vehicles but am basing my estimate on the usual cost of a democrat. If approved, may authority be granted to have Mr. Bunn purchase a suitable vehicle in Winnipeg?

With reference to Contract, I beg to recommend that the enclosed form be used in this connection. In the case of an Indian getting the contract, it would not be possible to obtain Bond for him, but in the case of a white man, I would recommend that the form of Bond be executed. With reference to para. 7, I would recommend a period of two weeks. With reference to Bond, should it be necessary to use this, I would like to be advised as to your wishes regarding the penal sum. Copies of other forms in connection with school vans also enclosed.

BETWEEN of the post office of in the Province of Manitoba, hereinafter called the Department Contractor of the First Part, and the Consolidated School District of Indian Affairs Fisher River Agency No. in the Province of Manitoba, hereinafter called the School District, of the Second Part.

2. The School District shall provide the van or conveyance, and the Contractor shall at all times provide that the conveyance shall arrive at the school aforesaid at least five minutes before the opening hour and leave the school immediately after the closing hour, the children to be taken on and left off at their respective homes, the driver to be at all times attentive to the said children while using the conveyance in full charge and to report forthwith any misconduct on the part of any of the said school children while in his charge to the principal of the said school.

3. The Contractor agrees to see that any heaters provided by the School District are properly attended to and kept in good working order during the trips to and from the school building during such period as the trustees of the School District shall direct, and further covenants that the average rate of travelling of the said conveyance both going and returning from the said school shall be at all times during the term of this Contract not less than four miles an hour.

4. The Contractor shall be responsible for and hereby covenants that all reasonable care shall be taken of such conveyance and equipment as may be supplied for his use by the said School District from time to time as well as of all equipment furnished by the said School District for the comfort of such school children from time to time, and shall deliver such conveyance and all such equipment to the School District at any time upon demand made by the said School District.

5. The School District may at any time, by giving notice in writing to the Contractor, make any change in the route aforesaid, such change to take effect at the expiration of three days from the giving of such notice, and the Contractor shall be bound to comply with such a change of route and to follow the new route laid down by the School District for the balance of the term covered by this Contract without extra remuneration if the said change does not entail a greater mileage being travelled by him than the present route providing there be any excess in mileage over the mileage to be travelled over the route laid down on the date of the execution of this Agreement to be travelled, the difference of such alteration of route shall be paid for by the School District at the same rate per mile as is now payable under this Agreement, or if the mileage is reduced the sum payable to the Contractor hereunder shall be reduced at the same rate per mile.

Sir,

Re Transportation of Children to Peguis South School.

Replying to your letter of May 21st past with reference to the above-stated matter, in which you state that the parents of the children living at too great a distance from the school should drive their children to school, or allow them the use of their ponies for this purpose, I beg to advise that the parents of such children who require transportation possess each only one team.

For the greater part of the time, the parents are dependent upon their teams to earn their living and there are few times when they would be available for the children to use. None of the parents have ponies, in fact, nearly all horses on the Peguis Reserve are in continuous use, farming, freighting, working on Provincial Roads, etc.

I would again recommend very strongly that a van be placed in operation for these children for the full 200 school days in each year, the period during early spring when roads are almost impassable excepted. The cost of such operation would not exceed $700 per annum and would be much cheaper than sending the children to Boarding School, even if the parents were willing to send them.

There are 12 children who reside at too great a distance to walk to school and the cost per capita at Boarding School of $175 per head would amount to $2100 whereas the cost of van is only $700, the saving by van being $1400.

If the children are transported only during the winter months, their education is not efficiently carried out. During the six months of summer, when they are absent from school, they lose all they have gained during the winter months.

I give hereunder a list of the children:

Reuben Cook - Age 12, Gordon Cook - Age 12,
Jas. Thomas - Age 8, Albert Cook - Age 8,
Edgar Thomas - Age 10, xMary Cook - Age 15,
Mary Thomas - Age 11, Martha Thomas - Age 12,
Muriel Olsen - Age 11, Lily Cook - Age 9,
Margaret Thomas - Age 7, Roderick Olsen - Age 13.
x This girl is still in the Primary Grade.
Three of the children who were travelling by van last winter are now walking to school. These are not included in the above list.
As stated in my previous letter, there is no suitable conveyance for the children in the vicinity and this would have to be supplied as is the custom with white schools in the District. Arrangements might be made to sell the conveyance to the Van Driver, he paying so much per month on same out of his earnings from transportation.

Ottawa, August 10, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, relative to the transportation to the Peguis South School of those children of the Peguis South Reserve who reside at too great a distance to otherwise attend. It is noted you recommend that a van be placed in operation to transport these children during the entire period the school is in operation during the next academic year. It is also noted that the cost of operating this van would be approximately $700 per annum.

The Department will approve of your making the best arrangements you can and at the lowest possible rate per day for the period beginning on or about September 1st, next, to the end of June, 1929. The Department will also approve of the purchase of a suitable conveyance for the purpose, to become the property of the driver upon his paying for same in monthly instalments out of his earnings from the transportation of the pupils. You should, if possible, obtain prices for the supplying of the conveyance, and you should make the purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price. You should state the deduction you would recommend be made from the amount due the driver each month in payment for the van. You should also inform the Department as to the rate per day arranged with the driver for the transportation of the children to and from their homes to the school. We have noted the names and ages of the children for whom it will be necessary to provide transportation.

An account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the van should be forwarded for payment. You should also forward accounts in the usual manner covering the amount due the driver for his services, with the deduction in payment of the cost of the van shown thereon.

Your obedient servant,

Form No. 101
Sir,

Re Transportation of Pupils - Peguis South School.

Reference your letter of August 10, 1928, I beg to advise that I was unable to secure the services of man suitably located on the Reserve to do this work until late in October. Teacher at the Peguis South School was resigning on October 30th and operation of van was therefore postponed until a new teacher had been appointed and school re-opened.

School re-opened in January past and the operation of van commenced on January 7th. With the exception of two days in January, when children were laid up with Influenza, the van has been in continuous operation during every school day until March 27th, school being closed that evening for the Easter holidays.

All bids received on this work were at the rate of $3.50 per day. The most dependable man and the one most conveniently located for this work was selected. The operation of the van has been very successful and, had it not been for the Influenza epidemic during the months of January and February, the average attendance would have been much greater during these months.

In explanation of my paying the driver in cash as per the attached Voucher No. 435 for the amount of $192.50 covering operation of the van from Jan. 7 to March 27, 1929, I beg to advise that the driver owed money on seed and other indebtedness and paid him in cash in order to make collection of this indebtedness more convenient.

I have written to Mr. Bunn in Winnipeg asking him to purchase a suitable wheeled vehicle for summer operation, said vehicle to be paid for by the Van Driver out of his earnings at so much per month. On receipt of this vehicle and knowing the price of same, I will advise the amount per month which will be collected from the Van Driver in payment of the vehicle. During the past winter, the children have been transported by sleigh. The Driver has a canvas covered in vehicle heated by a small stove and fitted with upholstered seats. The children have been very comfortable on their trips to and from the school even during the coldest weather.

Your obedient servant,

H. Tempelman,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, April 16, 1929.

Sir:

In this connection it is noted that you have requested Mr. Inspector Bunn to purchase a suitable wheeled vehicle for use in conveying the pupils during the summer, and that said vehicle is to be paid for by the van driver out of his earnings each month. When this vehicle is obtained, you should see that the driver arranges to make repayment of the cost of same.

You might inform the Department if the conveyance which was used in driving the pupils during the winter months has been paid for by the driver, as mentioned in your letter of August 3rd, last, which arrangement was approved in our letter of the 10th of the same month.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INDIAN AGENT TEMPLEMAN,
FOR THE MONTH OF APRIL, 1929, ON THE PEGUIS SOUTH
INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Original on File 136-5-7.

This school is an old log building 20 x 30. It is very much overcrowded and a larger building, preferably a two-roomed school with a junior and senior room is required. In a year or two, with the children in this vicinity growing up and attaining school age, the number of pupils on the roll will be 60 or more. Pupils are huddled so close together that it is a difficult matter for the teacher to maintain discipline and keep attention.
Ottawa, June 10, 1929.

Sir:

Referring to that portion of your report for the month of April, last, on the Peguis South Indian Day School regarding the condition of the present school building, I have to say that there are no funds provided in this year's estimates for the erection of a new building. This requirement has been noted for our estimates for the next school year.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

Geo. Stevenson, 565 Peguis Band, the van driver for the South Peguis School would like very much to purchase a large democrat for the conveyance of the children to the school. As he has no money, he is asking the Dept to finance this deal for him by deducting $25.00 per month from his pay cheque until paid in full.

He was in Winnipeg a short time ago and saw a rig which he said would suit, the price being $25.00.

If the Department would furnish the money to buy, I would suggest that Inspector Bunn of Winnipeg examine the rig mentioned, before buying. The present democrat he is using is too small for the work intended.

Your obedient servant,

C.A. Stevenson,
Indian Agent.

THE SECRETARY,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, August 22nd, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, relative to the request of George Stevenson, the van driver for the South Peguis Indian Day School, that the Department purchase a large democrat for his use in conveying the children to the school, and that the cost be deducted from his monthly pay cheque until paid in full.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of your arranging for the purchase of a suitable vehicle to transport the children to and from their homes. You should take up with Mr. Inspector Bunn, Winnipeg, the matter of his examining the rig the driver wishes to obtain before the purchase is made, and Mr. Bunn could, no doubt, arrange to complete the purchase, obtaining an account, in duplicate, which he could either certify himself or hand to you to be certified and forwarded to the Department for payment. You should see, in preparing the voucher in favour of Stevenson for the amount due him for his services each month, that the sum of $25 is deducted until full payment is made. You should clearly state on the voucher the reason for making the deduction, quoting the file number and date of this letter as your authority.

The purchase of this rig should receive early attention, in order that it can be on hand when George Stevenson starts transporting the children to school when it reopens.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

C. A. Stevenson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hedgson, Man.

Dear Sir:

On a recent visit to Peguis South School, I found the room pretty well crowded, 40 pupils in attendance, there 47 on the roll and about four new pupils expected to start at an early date. Miss Wright, the teacher is very short of desks, some of the children are sitting on boxes, others have boxes in front of them. She is asking the Dept. to give her 10 new single desks, 5 fronts and 5 rears, this will take all the room in the school.

I would recommend that they be granted as they can be used in a new school when it is built, which I hope will be next summer. It will require a two-room for South Peguis. I would also recommend that 6 new blinds for the windows be purchased as the present ones are very shabby and worn out.

The most of the desks in the school are the New Empire. (Moyer & Co., Wpg.)

Your obedient servant,

C. A. Stevenson,
Indian Agent.

THE SECRETARY,

You should arrange with this firm to supply the above at their lowest price to the Dominion Government.

PEGUIS SOUTH DAY SCHOOL.

At the time of my visit there were 43 children present, out of an enrolment of 58. Miss Jenny Wright is the teacher here, and from what I saw and heard I would say that she is doing good work. A great many of the parents pointed out to me how well their children were getting along in the school since Miss Wright came there. She, however, is working under great difficulties. In the first place her health is not good, although she was feeling better than she had been at the beginning of the winter. In the second place, the school is an old log building, very cold in the wintertime. The children were packed in there like sardines, with no room to get around at all, and Miss Wright informed me that she had nine different classes to teach, which must be very difficult in an overcrowded room. From what I gathered when going around the reserve, there are in the vicinity of that school about 70 children of school age, which is sufficient for two schools, and if a new Day School is going to be built here next summer I think this matter should receive consideration. The children from the southwest portion of the reserve come to the school by van, some of them I believe coming a distance of seven miles. A number of the children living in the southeast portion of the reserve do not come to school in the winter time on account of the distance that they have to travel. If we get the necessary school accommodation there before another winter sets in I think it would be well to consider the advisability of putting on another van for the southeast portion of the reserve, especially during the winter months.

-The-
Inspector Christianson's Report on Fisher River Schools.

The teacher's residence here is practically new, having been built in the Fall of 1928, and it is in a first-class state of repair.

In conclusion I wish to point out that the Day Schools above mentioned are doing good work, and I believe the children attend about as regularly as in the ordinary White settlement. In going around I found that a great many of the children could not even speak Indian, as in the majority of the homes the English language is spoken exclusively.

I mentioned that at the Fisher River School a midday meal is provided for the children. I think this should be considered at the other schools also, and when new schools are built I would suggest that a leanto kitchen be erected at the end of the building to provide a place where the meal could be prepared and served to the children. We have this arrangement at several of our Day Schools and it works out very satisfactorily. I may say that all the teachers mentioned this matter to me. Miss Wright, especially, pointed out that the lunch which many of the children brought with them was not sufficient, being merely bannock spread with lard. The ordinary midday meal given at the Day Schools is not expensive, but from past experience I can say that it is of great benefit to the children.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your No. 203-11 of the 1st instant, enclosing the report of Mr. Inspector Christianson on his inspection of the Peguis South Indian Day School.

With reference to the Inspector's report as to the need of a new school building to provide school facilities for all children of school age on that portion of the Peguis Reserve, I have to request that you will state whether you would advise that one building, having two classrooms, be erected at a location central to the requirements, or whether, in your opinion, it would be more satisfactory to erect two school buildings, having a classroom in each, on sites the most central to meet the requirements. As you are aware, at the present time a van is engaged to transport the children from the southwest portion of the Reserve, some having to travel a distance of nearly seven miles. After enquiring fully into the best arrangements that could be made to meet the requirements, I shall be pleased to have a report stating your views.

Dear Sir,

A new school at South Pigeon is I feel urgently needed. I believe both the Indian agent and the inspector have reported on conditions and advised building this spring. In planning the school I think some provision ought to be made for a sun porch or rest room where a couch could be kept for children who suffer from headaches etc. I have found it necessary frequently to bring children over to the teacher's cottage to rest. The children are, many of them, obliged to leave home very early and do not return until quite late. I feel that it would be a great help to have a place where they could rest if need be and it is not always possible to leave them in the cottage.

May I ask that you build me a garage also. I bought a car last fall & have secured a temporary building for a garage during the winter. It was anything but an asset to the property however and I'd be glad to have something more respectable.

It would improve the appearance of the property immensely if the ground in front of the residence could be levelled & seeded down.

I appreciate it very much if these things could be done this spring.

Yours truly,

J. Wright

Sir:-

Referring to your letter of the 9th ultimo No. 136-5-5 regarding the need of a new school building on the Peguis Reserve, in the Fisher River Agency, I may say that I have gone into the question as to whether it would be advisable to erect one building having two classrooms, at a location central to the requirements, or whether it would be more satisfactory to have two school buildings, having a classroom in each.

After careful consideration of the matter I have come to the conclusion that it would be much more advisable to have two separate schools, one on the site of the old school and the second one two miles West, across the river. I am told that there are about 70 children of school age in the district, and two separate buildings, with a capacity of 35 each is what is necessary. If this second school is built, across the river, there would be no further necessity for having a van to convey the children to school.

The cost of these buildings would be about $3000.00 for the schools, and $2000.00 for the teachers' residences.

In addition to this there is another school and teacherage required at the northern end of the Peguis Reserve, for which you stated last year and item was being noted for inclusion in the Estimates. I would suggest that this work be gone on with at the same time, if at all possible. This would mean an additional $5000.00 for the two buildings, school and teacherage.

Sir:

Replying to your letters Nos. 136-5-5 and 136-4-5 of the 2nd instant, I wish to inform you that I have already taken steps to erect a teacher's residence and school at Peguis North and a school at Peguis South. In connection with the site for this school, when Inspector Christianson last visited the school he held a meeting of the Indians on the South end of the reserve. Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, relative to the erection of new out houses at the Peguis South and Peguis North Indian Day Schools. It is noted that you are obtaining an estimate of the cost and will forward same later for the consideration of the Department.

Relative to the old school buildings at both the above schools, I beg to say that they may be given to any Indian who is willing to take them down and remove them from the school lot and level off the site on which they stand. It is noted that the Anglican missionary has spoken to you for these buildings. If you consider that he should have same rather than an Indian, the Department will approve of your making whatever arrangements you consider advisable. In any event, whoever removes the buildings should clear away all rubbish and level the site on which they stand.

Relative to the small frame residence at the North School, you may arrange for the disposal of same, which it is noted is worth approximately $50. If you succeed in disposing of this building to an Indian, you should obtain the purchase price, which should cover the material in the building and the removal of all rubbish and the levelling of the ground on which it is situated. Any amount received for this old residence should be forwarded to the Department for credit to the Receiver General.

I shall be glad if you will arrange to have these old buildings removed at an early date and the ground on which they stand properly levelled.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of February 17, No. 136-5-5 informing me that there are no funds with which to complete payment of labour in connection with the two schools and bungalow being built on the Peguis Reserve.

When these buildings were authorized in your letters of June 2, 136-5-5 and June 2, 136-4-5 I immediately began to make arrangements for their erection and made a contract with Mr. A.H. Packer to build the schools for $800.00 each and the bungalow for $850.00. Mr. Packer has received $1400.00 leaving a balance of $1050.00 due him, and as the buildings are completed he is very anxious to have his money. It will be a hardship to ask him to wait another five weeks for payment, which would mean a total delay of nearly two months since the Acting Agent sent me the account. I trust the Department will arrange to find funds from some source so that this account may be paid without any further delay.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Commissioner.

It is regretted that Mr. Packer will be put to inconvenience by delay in payment. Had these accounts been forwarded earlier, before our funds became exhausted, payment would have been made.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I am enclosing herewith a report on the various Day Schools in the Fisher River Agency, which were inspected by Mr. Christianson.

The report shows that good work is being done at all these schools. According to the Inspector, the teachers in charge seem to be very enthusiastic and are getting results.

On page five, under the heading of 'General' the Inspector speaks of a proposed school that is to be erected on the south end of the Peguis Reserve. I do not know whether it is the intention of the department to go ahead with this school or not. I should like to be advised.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
PEGUIS SOUTH DAY SCHOOL.

This school is taught by Miss Jenny Wright. There are 44 children on the register, and at the time of my visit there were 34 present. The grades taught are from 1 to 6. I found that the average attendance was about 35. I spent most of an afternoon in the classroom, and was well impressed with the work carried on. I think Miss Wright has splendid qualifications - not only has she her first class certificate, but she is a University graduate as well. She is working under a great handicap as there are often over 40 children in attendance in six different classes, and it is certainly quite a task. It is much different from teaching in a classroom where there is only one grade. I can conscientiously say that Miss Wright is giving her best efforts towards advancing the children who come to this school.

No mid-day meal is served at this school; the children have to bring their own lunch, but the usual biscuits are, of course, given out, and hot cocoa is also furnished.

A van brings the children from the south west corner of the reserve, but, as I have often mentioned before, the children from the north east corner of the reserve...
PEGUIS SOUTH DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

reserve have a long way to come.

A new school was built here last summer on the same plan as the North School. The teacher's bungalow was built two years ago.

GENERAL.

Last year the Department decided that another day school would be built on the south end of the reserve, and I picked out the site last May. If the Department propose to go on with the building of a new school and teacher's residence, as anticipated, I would like to go over the ground again as I am now under the impression that I can probably find a more central location. No doubt an Agent will soon be appointed, and if I am sent there to install him, I will go into this matter.

I might say that the day schools in this Agency are all carried on in a very satisfactory manner. The buildings are practically all new - both schools and dwellings. The buildings erected in 1929 and 1930 on the Peguis Reserve were all built by A. H. Packer & Sons, and I was very well satisfied with the workmanship. Mr. Packer is a first class carpenter, and all his work is done in a workmanlike manner.

To make everything complete, a mid-day meal should be served at the three schools on the Peguis Reserve. This would mean an extra expenditure at the North and South Schools as there are too many children there to enable the teacher to look after the preparation of the meal. A lean-to would also have to be built on the back of the schools to provide a kitchen and a place for the children to eat.
GENERAL (CONT'D.)

INDIAN COMMISSIONER, REGINA, DATED OCT. 20, 1931.

I regret to inform you that Miss Wright, teacher at the South Day School, declines to prepare the meal for her 47 pupils without assistance. Miss Wright was not asked to prepare the meal herself; she was asked to supervise the preparation of the meal by the older girls, which she might well do, and it seems to me that it would be in order to inform Miss Wright that she is expected to do this. This would be a splendid training for the girls, and to have an untrained Indian woman come in to do this work would be absurd. With your permission I will instruct Miss Wright that she is expected to oversee this work as part of her duties.
Ottawa, October 28, 1931.

Sir:

With reference to that portion of your 203-11A of the 20th instant, relative to the preparing and serving of a midday lunch to the pupils at the Peguis South Indian Day School, it is noted that the teacher, Miss Wright, requests that assistance be given her in carrying out this work.

In this connection I have to say it is considered that Miss Wright could have the older girls prepare and serve the meal under her supervision. She could arrange for two, or more if necessary, of the older girls to do this work each day, giving them the necessary instructions regarding the food to be prepared and in the preparing and serving of same, also in the washing and cleaning of the utensils used after the meal is served. The Department agrees with you that this would be a splendid training for the girls. It is expected that the teacher will oversee this work as part of her duties. I shall be pleased if you will instruct her accordingly.

If the supplies for the meal have not yet been obtained, I shall be pleased if you will arrange to make the purchase and have them delivered to the school at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, April 7th, 1933.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of Voucher 480, for $77.00, in favour of Geo. Stevenson, for transporting the children to the Peguis South Indian Day School during the month of March. As there is a deduction of 10% from this account, a cheque for $69.30 will be forwarded to you in payment of Stevenson's services.

Our appropriation this year has been considerably reduced and it is necessary to exercise every possible economy. Do you consider that the driving of the children to this school could be discontinued? If not, would it not be possible to discontinue the transportation of children during the months of May, June, September and October?

Please give this matter your immediate consideration and let me have your recommendation with a view to curtailing the cost of this service to the greatest possible extent.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

G. H. Lavender, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Man.
Dear Sir:

Reference to your letter 136-5-5 and the question of the transportation of the children to the Peguis South Day School.

I fully realize the necessity for economy and would gladly recommend the curtailment of this service if it was feasible. Attached you will find a descriptive map of the situation which I trust you will find of some benefit to you in reviewing the situation. You will note that the location of the school is not at all central and is placed in the northeastern corner of the school district thus making the attendance of the children at the school impossible without transportation.

The question of moving the school is impossible and even if the buildings could be moved there would still be distances of four and five miles for the children to travel. As shown on the map, the children at the west end of the reserve are between eight and nine miles distant from the school. Therefore, if the van route were eliminated during the months suggested none of the pupils west of Hodgson could be expected to attend school on account of the distance to travel.

One solution I had in mind was to try and make arrangements with the school Trustees of the Hodgson village school for the accommodation of the children living west of Hodgson. This, however, I was unable to accomplish for the Hodgson school is already over crowded and unable to fully accommodate local conditions.

If it is imperative that transportation be cut, I would recommend that same be eliminated during the months of January and February. At that period of the year attendance is never very high. I am not honestly recommend the elimination of the van route during the months of May, June, September and October for this would mean too much loss of schooling to the pupils concerned.

The matter of the cost of transportation can hardly be reduced for at the present time the van driver is paid $3.50 less 35¢ per day of travel. He has to keep two teams, supply his own equipment, a covered van on wheels, a covered sleigh, stove and heating and his route covers about thirty miles per day from the time he leaves his home until his return and I doubt very much if we could get any body else to give this service for less money.

I will gladly co-operate in the question of economy as it refers to schools generally, but in this case outside of what I have suggested I am unable to see where costs can be cut.

Your obedient servant,

G. H. Lavender,
Indian Agent

THE SECRETARY,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, April 20, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, regarding the transportation of the children to the Peguis South Indian Day School. The descriptive map which you enclosed showing the location of the school and where the Indians reside has been noted.

While the Department is anxious to cut expenditure for the present fiscal year at every possible point, we are, in view of your report and the distance the greater number of children have to travel, approving of the continuing of the transportation of the children to and from school during the entire school year. The employment of George Stevenson, providing he is giving satisfactory service, may be continued at the same rate as previously paid, viz., $3.50 per day, less ten percent. Accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of the transportation services should be forwarded as formerly at the end of each month.

I note you recommend the elimination of this service during the months of January and February. Early in December, next, you should refer this matter to the Department and state whether you are of opinion that this service could be discontinued during the two months mentioned. We will be in a position at that time to decide as to the state of the funds for the purpose of transporting the pupils.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

THE SECRETARY,

Ottawa, December 9, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, regarding the transportation of children to the Peguis South Indian Day School. It is noted you recommend that this service be continued throughout the entire school year but that, if funds are limited, the driving of the children might be discontinued in either January and February, when the winter is most severe, or in April and May, during the break-up, when roads are more or less impassable.

The Department is anxious to cut expenditure at every possible point, and, as you are in the best position to judge conditions at this school, it is thought that the service might be discontinued for two months, either January and February or April and May. The Department will leave this matter in your hands, to arrange for transportation facilities during the present winter and coming spring months, in order that a saving can be effected in expenses, by discontinuing the services for a two month period. You might advise the Department later during which months you consider the service in transporting the children should be eliminated, in the interests of effecting a saving in cost.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Re Pequiss South School

I wish to advise that the well at the above school has caved in and will have to be cleaned out and a new crib put in. This could be done at an approximate cost of $20.00, $10.00 for labor and $10.00 for lumber and nails for crib.

The three outside closets at this school will have to be moved. The cost of this moving would be approximately $10.00.

An item of $19.00 was placed in our 1936-37 estimates for the interior decoration of the teacher's residence at this school. This amount would cover labor and material.

I might add that an item of $20.00 was placed in our estimates for fence and general repairs. Could this be applied to fixing up the well.

I would be glad of your authority for whatever expenditure is possible so the work can be done as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

F. J. Clarke,
Indian Agent

Dear Sir:

I beg to report as follows on the Peguis South Day School, which was inspected on October 5th.

Here, again, the buildings are badly in need of exterior painting. The residence has been well kept and the furniture is in splendid condition.

Miss Field had a splendid garden of flowers and vegetables. She also had a new lawn seeded and has certainly spared no effort on her part to improve the surroundings. The Indians were greatly pleased with these improvements and we hope they will benefit by the example.

Ottawa, November 6, 1936.

Dear Sir:

In reviewing the return of the Peguis South Indian Day School for the month of September, it is found that, while there was an enrolment of 34, the average attendance was only 24. This seems small in view of the fact that we are allowing $3.50 a day for driving the children to school.

Please let me know at once if George Stevenson, Jr., is performing his duties in a proper manner and also state why the average attendance was comparatively low during the month of September. You might also let me know the average attendance during the month of October.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

F. J. Clarke, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Man.
Dear Sir:

I have your letter 136-5-5 of Nov 6/36 re the van driver and the attendance at the Peguis South School.

During the month of October there were 46 on the roll at this school, the average attendance is 28.4. There are several children away from school with colds.

With reference to the van driver I would state that there are nine children on the van route which is south and west from this school. These children are attending school regularly, the absentees are from the area east of the school. The matter of regular attendance is being taken up with the parents.

Your obedient servant,

F. J. Clarke,
Indian Agent

Ottawa, March 23, 1940.

Dear Mr. Clark:

I am just in receipt of a letter from George Stevenson, Jr., No. 1150, who, I believe, drives the van down there. This letter was marked with a special delivery stamp and he states that he has not received the December, January or February cheques. Therefore, I suppose that this man is being pushed by his creditors, and as he has a large family I am quite aware that it makes it very awkward for him.

I immediately checked this matter up with the Schools Branch and find that the reason Stevenson has not received the three cheques he mentions is that they are out of funds in the vote from which this is payable. They have made application to the Treasury Board to transfer funds from another vote, but this authority has not come through yet. The accounts, however, are all ready for payment just as soon as this transfer is made, and you can assure George Stevenson and his creditors that there is no danger of him not receiving the money directly on completion of this transfer. I, therefore, trust that you will be able to arrange for any credit that George Stevenson requires in the meantime until he receives the cheques in question.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

General Superintendent of Agencies.

Indian Agent,

Ottawa, June 19, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Due to conditions at present confronting us, every possible economy must be effected in order to enable us to carry on necessary work. With this in mind, I have reviewed the expenditures at the Peguis South Indian Day School and noted that there is a heavy expenditure for the transportation of children. In spite of this fact, the attendance figures show that the average attendance for the past four quarters has been only 70% of the enrolment. It might be inferred from this that the driving of the children has no appreciable effect on the attendance.

Is it necessary to drive the children to this school? How many use the van? Even though it may be necessary to drive some children during the winter months, why is it necessary to drive them during the fine weather? I would appreciate receiving a report from you in regard to this matter and I am hopeful that you will offer a recommendation that will reduce the expenditure for the transportation of children to a considerable extent.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. F. J. Clarke,
Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge Departmental letter dated September 21, File 136-5-5, regarding a van to take children to the South Peguis Indian Day School.

I find that there are 6 or 8 children residing from four to six miles distant from the South Peguis School. I think the Department will agree that this is too far to expect children to walk. It might be advisable to see if arrangements can be made for these children to attend the public school in Hodgson. If this could be done I think the use of a van might be discontinued.

In any event, unless the weather becomes extremely cold, the attendance at school might not be greatly affected if the van were discontinued until December 31st, and then put in operation through January, February, March and April.

I think this arrangement might have a good effect on the minds of the Indians. They would perhaps realize that they had not had their children make the best use of the privileges provided for them.

If the Department approves of the suggestion that the children attend the Hodgson day school, I think no doubt Mr. Clarke could make the necessary arrangements if instructed to do so.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
