Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of September 12 and previous correspondence with reference to the operation of the van at the Peguis South School.

It is understood that there are 6 or 8 children residing from 4 to 6 miles distant from this school and we have been advised that it might be possible to arrange to have these children attend the public school at Hodgson. If this could be done the use of the van might be discontinued. Please interview the authorities of the Hodgson public school and ascertain if they are willing to accept these children and, if so, the yearly amount they would charge the Department for their tuition.

I am inclined to feel that the attendance at this school would not be greatly affected if the van were not operated between now and the end of December. We will, however, be prepared to favourably consider operating the van during the months of January, February, March and April provided you are not successful in arranging with the public school authorities at Hodgson to accept the children residing a comparatively short distance from that school.

Yours truly,

I beg to advise that the Indians of Fisher River Band have requested that the school van, which was in operation for a part of the last school term, be operated for the whole of the next school term for the children who live at a considerable distance from the school, and I would recommend that their request be complied with. The cost of operating this van was $3.50 per school day.

The Indians of Peguis reserve, who have children too far from the Peguis South school have requested that if our proposed plan for renting the south church hall and dividing this school into two rooms, under two teachers, goes through, two vans be operated to convey about 26 children to school, who live from 3 to 6 miles from the school. This is a reasonable request I think, as at present there are at least that many children now, of school age, who have never had a day at school. If however, the plan of dividing this school is not consummated, it would be no use bringing these children to the school, as there would be no accommodation for them, and the one van, which was operated last term would be sufficient. Will you please advise?

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLICQUES CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept' of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Peguis South Indian Day School

With reference to Mr. B.F. Neary's letter, File 136-6-1 (W T) of the 7th July last, I beg to advise THAT we can procure the use of the Anglican Church Hall connected with the Peguis South Church, for use as an extra class room for the Peguis South School, at a rental of $15.00 per month. This hall is in very good shape and has been well kept. It is very clean. The only drawback is, that it has only three windows on each side, which is probably not sufficient lighting for school purposes. However, it is not at all bad. The teacher for this class room, if she lives at the teacher's residence, would have to walk about three quarters of a mile each way to and from the school.

If the use of this hall is approved, it will be necessary to equip it with school desks etc; and I enclose herewith a requisition in triplicate for these items.

With reference to scribblers, text books, etc; the teacher has prepared already a requisition for these requirements for the whole school, and it is thought that the requirements for that portion of the school located in the church hall could be taken from this supply.

Please advise at an early date the decision of the Department regarding the above proposals.

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.
AIRMAIL

Ottawa, August 13, 1947.

Mr. P. G. Lazenby, Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Manitoba.

Peguis South Indian Day School

The Department approves the opening of an extra classroom at the Peguis South Indian Day School. Please advise the Church of England officials that we approve the payment of a rent of $15.00 a month for this classroom, effective the date this school opens.

We are arranging to forward the desks and blackboard. We will also arrange to forward extra pencils and scribblers, as these will probably be required.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
